Antibody tests for all citizens living or working in Andorra will allow them to know the degree of immunization of COVID-19. A fact that will reinforce the control and management of the epidemiological situation and that at the same time will favour the move from a strategy of total confinement to one of selective confinement of the people infected by the coronavirus and his contacts. In this way, the protection of the most vulnerable citizens is enhanced and at the same time minimizes the probability of contagion in the work and school environment. The tests, consisting of a practically painless finger prick, will be performed free of charge to everyone.  There will be two tests to all citizens in two waves, separated by fifteen days, being the final result of the test the sum of the two tests. That is, two tests that offer a single result. In this sense, people who test positive in the first analysis of antibodies will be warned and isolated in order to take a PCR test and check if they have the disease at that time. The rest of the citizens, after the first test, will receive instructions on what to do and will obtain a final result when both tests have been done.  https://archive.vn/O1yU0

As of 19 December, entry is prohibited to third-country nationals when arriving from any states except those listed as safe countries.    For Austrian citizens and residents of Austria, EU, UK, Switzerland, and safe countries, a 10-day self-quarantine is mandatory when arriving from a risk area.     After 5 days of quarantine at the earliest, an antigen or PCR test can be taken. If the test is negative, no further quarantine is needed.     Safe countries: Australia, Finland, Ireland, Iceland, Japan, New Zealand, Norway, South Korea, Uruguay, and the Vatican.   All other countries are considered risk areas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219062547/https://www.austria.info/en/service-and-facts/coronavirus-information/entry-regulations
08 Jan: Beginning at midnight, Austria will again enforce border controls to Czechia and Slovakia  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104122951/https://metropole.at/coronavirus-in-austria-week-1-2021/

From 15 January, all travellers entering Austria will need to register electronically in advance and obtain a so-called pre-travel clearance (PTC). At the border, they will have to show their PTC (either digitally or as a hard copy). In parallel with this registration requirement, the current quarantine obligation remains in force until further notice, “testing oneself free” (“Freitesten”) is possible after 5 days at the earliest. Exceptions to quarantine and registration requirements apply to commuters, transients and persons entering the country for urgent family matters that cannot be postponed.  The only countries exempt from the quarantine obligation, but not from the registration requirement, are Australia, Finland, Greece, Iceland, Japan, New Zealand, Norway, Singapore, South Korea and Vatican.    https://archive.fo/7jXrE  https://archive.vn/m4Yeg

As of 19 December, short-time work is still available.      Short-time work supports companies in order to keep as many employees as possible in the company, even in times of financial crisis. The employment service (AMS) takes over the majority of the salary payments.     Short-time working cannot be requested by individual employees; this decision can only be made by the company itself. In general, support can only be given to companies that have been severely affected by the current corona crisis and have thus got into a critical financial situation.    80-90% of the salary will be covered during short-time work.    The Corona short-time work is currently limited to a duration of 3 months. This time frame can later be extended by a further 3 months.    In principle, all employees subject to unemployment insurance are eligible for short-time work, provided they have a fully paid calendar month before starting short-time work.    Members of the executive body are eligible if they are ASVG-insured; also board members who are subject to the ASVG.    Apprentices are eligible.    Freelance workers are eligible if normal working hours can be shown.    Marginally employed persons, civil servants, one-person entrepreneurs and shareholders-managing directors subject to GSVG are not covered by the short-time working regulations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201220015045/https://www.bmafj.gv.at/Kurzarbeit-Infoseite.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20201220015310/https://www.bmafj.gv.at/Services/News/Coronavirus/FAQ--Kurzarbeit.html

Several measures are still in place including new phase of short-term work arrangement (until March 2021), fixed cost subsidy (March 2021), hardship fund for small businesses (March 2021). Unemployment assistance has however been discontinued end-2020.    https://archive.vn/9dis2

No policy change    As of 19 December, loan deferral is still possible for borrowers who can no longer meet their payment obligations from consumer loans.     The statutory measures provide for a statutory right to defer payments that are to be made in the period from April 1, 2020 to January 31, 2021 on the basis of a consumer credit agreement. This means that if necessary, flat-rate installments (installments including principal and interest payments), capital repayments or interest payments can be suspended (deferred) for 10 months in full.    The deferral means that the payments owed in the deferral period will be postponed to future dates. The law provides that the deferred 10 months are added to the agreed term of the loan agreement - the term of the loan is extended by 10 months. However, instead of extending the term, borrowers can also agree with the bank that the deferred installments will be made up later.     Since the right to deferment was laid down in law, banks are not allowed to charge any charges (processing fee) for the deferral.    The law also stipulates that the bank may not terminate a consumer loan - i.e. loans, overdrafts and foreign currency loans - in the period from 01/04/2020 to 01/31/2021. This means that for loans, a maturity due to missing installments, which would have been paid between 01/04/2020 and 01/31/2021, is not possible. In the case of account overdrafts, the law means that a bank can make the overdraft due for repayment on February 1, 2021 at the earliest.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201220023025/https://www.arbeiterkammer.at/beratung/konsument/Geld/Kredite/Geldsorgen_mit_Kredit_durch_Corona.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20201220023331/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The website includes current coronavirus information, current measures, vaccination information, frequently asked questions, coronavirus hotlines, legal information, and the corona traffic light.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201220035621/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus

Population-wide testing was carried out between 4 December and 15 December, depending upon the region. The tests were free and optional.     All citizens of school age and older who live in Austria were able to participate. People who were in Austria for work or study reasons were also allowed to participate. Minors needed to be accompanied by a legal guardian.    Persons not tested included those who had symptoms that indicated COVID-19 disease, were on sick leave due to another illness, were in official segregation in the last three months because of a SARS-CoV-2 positive test, were in quarantine, isolation or domestic isolation, have already been reserved a test for another official appointment, are regularly tested for professional reasons, and children before compulsory schooling.    As of 14 December, 22% of the population had participated – far short of the 60% the government initially said it was aiming for.     "It's a successful step to contain the pandemic in Austria," Health Minister Rudolf Anschober told a press conference, adding that two million people across the country had participated in the voluntary tests out of a population of 8.8 million.  "In the future, we want to reach groups that have not yet responded positively to the tests. We are reviewing a large number of possible courses of action.”    https://web.archive.org/web/20201220043053/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Haeufig-gestellte-Fragen/FAQ--Testungen-und-Quarantaene.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20201220040926/https://www.thelocal.at/20201214/austria-defends-unpopular-mass-testing-scheme

A second round of mass COVID testing started in Vienna, on Friday 8 January, Copied from page https://www.ruptly.tv/en/videos/20210108-032-Austria--Vienna-begins-second-COVID-mass-testing-campaign    https://archive.vn/Z72Hk      https://archive.fo/7jXrE#selection-2509.0-2511.63

No policy change    As of 19 December, contact tracing is still in place.     Contact persons are defined as persons with defined contact to a confirmed case during the time period of infectivity (48 hours before the onset of the disease, up to 10 days after the onset of the disease).    Contact tracers notify persons which shared the same environment as the confirmed case. Depending on how long and intensive the contact was with this person, one is identified as contact person K1 or K2. Further instructions are then given depending upon this classification.    “Stop Corona” app is Austria’s official contact tracing app which automatically records any and all contacts while adhering to strict data protection guidelines. As soon as a user reports an infection, all contacts are automatically notified. Use of the app is optional.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201220043053/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Haeufig-gestellte-Fragen/FAQ--Testungen-und-Quarantaene.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20201220044213/https://www.austria.info/en/service-and-facts/coronavirus-information/app

No policy change    As of 19 December, mouth and nose protection must be worn in the following areas:  – All closed rooms that are open to the public  – Public transport, planes, taxis and taxi-like operations (including stops, stations, and departure halls)  – Connecting structures in shopping centers    In public places, all persons who do not live in their own household must keep one meter away. When meeting in closed public spaces, a distance of one meter must be kept and mouth and nose protection must be worn.    It is not compulsory to wear mouth and nose protection outdoors, with the exception of the events listed in Section 12 of the ordinance (e.g. demonstrations, funerals). Regarding this, there may be regional rules of their own.    In the workplace, mouth and nose protection must be worn in closed rooms if physical contact with other people cannot be ruled out and the risk of infection cannot be minimized by other suitable protective measures (e.g. by means of a technical protective device such as partition or plexiglass walls).     If technical protective measures make it impossible to carry out the work (e.g. for actors), organizational protective measures (such as the formation of permanent teams) must be provided instead.    Employees and employers can mutually agree on stricter regulations regarding the wearing of mouth and nose protection.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219044559/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/

As of 19 December, there is no COVID-19 vaccine available in Austria.    There will be free vaccines for all people in Austria who want to be vaccinated. The republic will buy the vaccines centrally and distribute them to many places, which will then carry out the vaccinations.    The federal government and other government representatives have repeatedly emphasized that there will be no general compulsory vaccination.    The first effective, safe and effective vaccines in relevant quantities could be available in Austria from the beginning of 2021. The crucial point is the central European approval for the European Union. Only then will the vaccines meet the statutory quality requirements.    Because not enough vaccines will be initially available to vaccinate everyone at the same time, the people who are at the highest risk will be vaccinated at the beginning. After that all others can be vaccinated step by step.     “We are confident that by the 2nd quarter there will be enough vaccines available to vaccinate anyone who wishes to be vaccinated.”    https://web.archive.org/web/20201220054442/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Haeufig-gestellte-Fragen/FAQ--COVID-19-Impfung.html

A, C:  The vaccination process against Covid-19 in Austria started on December 27.    The first target group are people over the age of 65, especially in old people's and nursing homes, and all the staff in these homes.    The BioNTech and Pfizer vaccines will be used.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210105170444/https://www.vindobona.org/article/covid-19-vaccine-austria-starts-on-december-27  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111122126/https://www.krone.at/2282944

From 14 December 2020 to 18 January 2021, strict quarantine measures are implemented in specified localities. It requires that all non-essential businesses remain closed, and all non-essential activities banned. Exceptions are limited to the activities of grocery stores, pharmacies, security forces, healthcare providers, utility service providers, freight services, and financial services. Access to these cities will be controlled; police checkpoints have been erected on approaches to these areas. "Vaccination of Azerbaijan’s population against Covid-19 will start in early 2021 following the finalization of negotiations for the purchase of vaccines. Authorities in the country defined scientifically substantiated safety as the key criteria a vaccine should meet.    “Now, when the vaccination process begins in the world, we are also involved in these activities. For many of the past months, negotiations were held with leading vaccine manufacturers such as Sputnik V, AstraZeneca, Sinopharm, Sinovac, Moderna, Pfizer BioNTech,” President Ilham Aliyev said in a virtual meeting of the CIS Heads of States Council on Friday, according to Azertag.Az.     “We have also developed a vaccination strategy, which implies a multi-platform approach. And regardless of what technologies are used, the main criterion for us will be the scientifically based safety of these vaccines. There are plans that the vaccination program will begin early next year, will be voluntary and carried out at the expense of the state.”    http://web.archive.org/web/20201231101019/https://caspiannews.com/news-detail/azerbaijan-reveals-vaccination-plans-amidst-negotiations-with-major-vaccine-developers-2020-12-19-31/

All passenger travel (by air, by rail and by sea) from the United Kingdom to Belgium is prohibited on Monday, December 21, 2020. This applies both to passengers with Belgium as their final destination as well as to passengers in transit through the country. Belgium extends financial aid to businesses affected by coronavirus measures. The Council of Ministers approved a royal decree extending to January the doubling of financial allowance for independents affected by Covid-19 measures.  In December, it covers independents in the hospitality, events, entertainment, culture, fairs, markets, travel, hairdressing and beauty sectors. The double “droit de passerelle” (transitional allowance) as the mechanism is called, grants independents without family responsibilities 2,583.40 euros per month in Covid-19 support, while those with families are eligible for 3,228.20 euros. The mechanism, which initially covered October and November, was first extended to December, and now covers the month of January, pending the implementation of a new system next year.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201215140729/https://www.brusselstimes.com/news/belgium-all-news/145101/belgium-doubles-financial-allowance-for-independents-affected-by-covid-19-measures/

On 21 December 2020, the EMA issued a positive opinion on the biontech/Pfizer vaccine and it was subsequently approved by the European Commission. On 28 December, this vaccine was administered for the first time in 3 Belgian residential care centres (located in Puurs, Brussels and Mons). From 5 January, this vaccination will be rolled out in all residential care centres. Currently, vaccines from two other companies, Moderna and Astra Zeneca/Oxford, are also undergoing the strict control of the EMA. The Moderna vaccine will be reviewed on 6 January 2021. If successful, the European Commission can give its final approval and green light for the use of this vaccine. Other potential vaccines will be examined later, including those from Johnson & Johnson or Curevac.      Will the vaccine be available to everyone from the start?  No. The vaccines will be produced continuously and quantity available will increase as they are delivered. Pending their large-scale production, several steps should be planned to best protect the most vulnerable groups and gradually increase individual immunity. (see question “Who are the priority groups?")  At the moment, it is difficult to provide a precise schedule for the administration of these vaccines. Therefore, monitoring the progressive availability of the vaccine per priority group is crucial.    To increase the population’s immunity and to protect those most vulnerable from the virus, vaccination will take place in three phases, depending on the number of doses available.    GROUP 1a    First, the most vulnerable and exposed people will be vaccinated.    Residents and employees of residential care centres and collective care institutions: since the outbreak of the pandemic, COVID-19 has hit elderly people hard, especially those living in residential care centres. They will be vaccinated first, followed by the staff (including volunteers), followed by collective care institutions.  The medical staff from primary care and hospitals: they are in close contact with patients with Covid-19 on a daily basis. To protect them, they are vaccinated as a matter of priority.  Next, the other staff in hospitals and health services will be vaccinated, including organisations responsible for prevention activities, such as vaccination and cancer screening centres, ONE and Kind en Gezin.  In this first phase, this will require a special organisation and infrastructure (extremely low storage temperatures, multiple doses, etc.).    GROUP 1b : vulnerable people without acute medical problems but at high risk    In this phase it is expected that vaccines will become more widely available. It will then be possible to vaccinate larger groups of people. Priority will be given to people outside the hospital who are most at risk. These are the following groups:    People over 65: people over 65 are the first priority at this stage. If sufficient vaccine is available, all these people can be vaccinated at the same time. Otherwise we start with the oldest people and then work our way down.  People between 45-65 years of age with an increased risk: Then people between 45-65 years come with risk factors, such as:  Diabetes,  Hypertension, Chronic cardiovascular, pulmonary, kidney and liver disorders, haematological cancers up to 5 years after diagnosis,  All recent cancers (or recent cancer treatments)  Obesity (Body Mass Index = 30).  This list will be updated and expanded in the light of scientific developments,    Essential professions: In this phase, people with essential social and/or economic professions are vaccinated. In this second phase, we can expect fewer logistical bottlenecks and organising the vaccination will be easier for these target groups.  GROUP 2 - general population    Thirdly, vaccine doses will be available in sufficient quantities to vaccinate the rest of the population.    At this stage it can be expected that the doses can be stored and administered like other vaccines such as the flu vaccine).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115165454/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/vaccination/    Note: Belgium was criticised for being slow off the mark with vaccinations:  About 700 residents and staff of care homes have gotten their first shot as of January 2, when the government provided its latest update on the tally. In Germany, by contrast, roughly 317,000 doses have been administered, and about 182,000 in Italy. Yves Van Laethem, an infectious diseases specialist and spokesman for Belgium's COVID-19 crisis center, said the country is also getting fewer doses than initially promised by Pfizer — only 320,000 instead of 600,000 by late December — forcing the government to make a choice between healthcare workers and the elderly. They said they would prioritise the elderly. Hence only one group have been vaccinated in this early stage.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210107121941/https://www.politico.eu/article/belgium-government-criticism-coronavirus-vaccine-campaign-frank-vandenbroucke/    Other notes:  Belgium received its first batch of 9,750 vaccines last Saturday (Dec 26, 2020) and began vaccinating  between 300 and 400 people today.     Residents and staff of care homes and health care professionals will be the first to be vaccinated. Vaccinations started in three care homes across Belgium (Woluwe-Saint-Pierre in Brussels, Mons in Wallonia and Puurs in Flanders, where the BioNTech/Pfizer vaccine was produced).    Under the second phase of the plan, people over 65, patients between 45 and 65 years old at high risk from the virus due to obesity or lung disease, and people with essential jobs will get their shot. Finally, other at-risk patients and the rest of the adult population will be vaccinated.    The timing of the different phases will depend on how many doses are available at different times, and how difficult it is to store the vaccines.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104165332/https://www.euronews.com/2020/12/28/covid-vaccine-man-96-is-first-to-receive-coronavirus-jab-in-belgium  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104165542/https://www.politico.eu/article/what-you-need-to-know-about-belgiums-vaccination-strategy/

The government announced it is updating its Covid-19 vaccination roll-out plan which has been widely criticized for being slow. Only 700 doses were used, out of the 10,000+ vaccine doses delivered on December 28, 2020.     Professor Corinne Vandermeulen, a professor at the KU Leuven Vaccinology Department says, "we're doing the best we can. And of course there can be critics and I know that people criticize the fact that we choose to vaccinate the people in the long term care facilities first and that we might have started with healthcare workers maybe first instead of the elderly. But the elderly, they are the most vulnerable."    By the start of this week, only 700 of the over 10 thousand vaccine doses delivered to Belgium by an EU scheme on December 28th had been put into people's arms.    The only jab approved in the EU so far is the one from Pfizer-BioNtech.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210107181631/https://www.euronews.com/2021/01/06/belgium-to-launch-new-coronavirus-vaccine-strategy-amid-criticism-for-a-slow-roll-out
Still just care homes and the very elderly https://web.archive.org/web/20210115165454/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/vaccination/

Attended classes (including internships, external classes, exams, dual training system, etc.) in schools and personal development support centers are suspended.    The present learning process in the higher schools is suspended, except for the holding of state exams.    Attended group classes in language centers, educational centers and other training centers and schools organized by legal entities and individuals are suspended.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102180723/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

As of December 17, measures of November 27 remain effective until January 31 instead of expiring on December 21; nightclubs, gaming, casinos, restaurants, sports; shopping malls and conferences/congresses/in-person seminars/theatres/museums/galleries/cinemas closed; banks/payment services, pharmacies and food shops not closed; source: /web/20201221113138/https://sofiaglobe.com/2020/12/17/most-of-bulgarias-stricter-measures-against-covid-19-extended-to-end-january/

On 22 December, order RD-01-718 went into effect. Order RD-01-675 also remains in effect.    Employers and recruitment bodies are to organize the work process of employees in remote form (teleworking / home work), where possible, allowing the presence of a maximum of 50% of staff.    The work process of the collective management bodies and the employees should be carried out, if possible, in remote form (home work / remote work) or to establish working hours with variable limits or work in shifts. Employers to approve a schedule for the use of regulated holidays, where applicable, as well as to apply other preventive measures and methods of work, depending on the specifics of the respective work activity, which will provide a better level of protection of workers.    Visits to shopping centers (representing one or more buildings in which shops, restaurants and other commercial sites are located) are suspended, except for grocery stores, hospitals, pharmacies, drugstores, opticians, pet stores, banks, insurers, payment service providers, offices of telecommunications operators and other providers of communications and utility services and dry cleaning services therein. Visits to gambling halls and casinos are also suspended.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102180723/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

As of December 17, measures of November 27 remain effective until January 31 instead of expiring on December 21; conferences/congresses/in-person seminars/theatres/museums/galleries/cinemas closed; source: /web/20201221113138/https://sofiaglobe.com/2020/12/17/most-of-bulgarias-stricter-measures-against-covid-19-extended-to-end-january/

On 22 December, order RD-01-718 went into effect.    The holding of sports events with training and competitive character in the collective sports for persons under 18 years of age is suspended. An exception is allowed only for registered athletes to sports federations. Sports competitions for all age groups are held without an audience.    All cultural and entertainment events (cinemas, museums, galleries, stage events, concerts, classes in dance, creative and musical arts, etc.) are suspended. An exception is allowed with regard to the theaters, when the seats are occupied up to 30% of their total capacity, observance of a physical distance of at least 1.5 m and mandatory placement of protective face masks.    The holding of congress-conference events, seminars, competitions, trainings, team building, exhibitions and other public events in attendance is suspended. The ban does not apply to competitions held in accordance with the Labor Code, the Civil Servant Act, the Academic Staff Development Act in the Republic of Bulgaria and other special laws.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102180723/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

As of December 17, 2020, nightclubs, gaming halls, casinos, restaurants, shopping malls, sports, conferences, congresses and in-person seminars halls will remain closed until January 31; theatres, museums, galleries and cinemas may re-open from January 1 with a limitation of use of no more than 30 per cent seating capacity; source: /web/20201221130909/https://sofiaglobe.com/2020/12/17/most-of-bulgarias-stricter-measures-against-covid-19-extended-to-end-january/

On 22 December, order RD-01-718 went into effect.    It is not allowed to organize and hold gatherings and celebrations of a private nature (weddings, baptisms, funerals, etc.) with the presence of more than 15 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102180723/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

As of 3 January, public transport remains open with mask wearing requirements.    All persons when in closed public places, including means of public transport and other places where citizens have access to railway and bus stations, airports, and metro stations, must have a protective face mask for single or multiple use or other means covering the nose and mouth.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210102180723/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki
As of 3 January, no stay-at-home measures are in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102180723/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

As of 3 January, there are no restrictions on internal movement between regions of Bulgaria.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210102192215/https://bg.usembassy.gov/novel-coronavirus-covid-19-information/
Ban on high-risk regions; source: /web/20201221130140/https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/international-travel-covid?stackMode=absolute&time=2020-12-20®ion=World

As of 3 January, orders RD-01-719 and RD-01-725 remain in effect.    A temporary ban has been introduced for the entry into the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria of all persons, regardless of their citizenship, through all border crossings, by air, sea, rail and road transport.     The ban does not apply to Bulgarian citizens, citizens of Member States of the European Union (EU), Schengen Parties (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the Vatican City State) and their family members (including persons in actual residence with them); citizens of the Union of Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, the Republic of Rwanda, the Republic of Korea, the Kingdom of Thailand, the Republic of Tunisia, the Oriental Republic of Uruguay, the United Arab Emirates, Ukraine, the Republic of Northern Macedonia, the Republic of Serbia and the Republic of Albania Herzegovina, Montenegro, the Republic of Moldova, Israel, the State of Kuwait, the Republic of Belarus and the Republic of Turkey; the persons with the status of permanent, long-term or long-term residence on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria and the members of their families; persons holders of a Bulgarian long-stay visa type "D", as well as persons who have a residence permit in a Member State of the European Union or in a Schengen country (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the Vatican City State) and members of their families.     A temporary ban has been introduced for entering the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria through all border crossings, by air, sea, rail and road transport of all persons arriving with a starting point of departure from the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.    The prohibition does not apply to Bulgarian citizens and persons with the status of permanent, long-term or long-term residence on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria, to members of their families, as well as to other groups of persons specified in the order.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102180723/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Rather general statement on support as of December 17, 2020, such as allocation of BGN 1,024 million to the state-owned company "The Fund of Funds" to provide subsidies to micro enterprises, self-employed, entrepreneurs from vulnerable groups, and eligible SMEs and companies, and allocation of BGN 418 million to the Urban Development Funds, managed by the Fund of Funds, for long-term investment and working capital, targeting municipalities, PPPs and businesses, hit by the crisis, including tourism and transport; source: /web/20201221134035/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

On 23 December, the 60/40 measure in support of business and workers was extended until September 2021    "Eligible applicants for the measure are employers from the sectors of passenger and urban transport, passenger land transport, hotels, restaurants. Self-employed persons with activity in the same sectors, as well as freelancers and sole traders are also entitled to assistance in this line," said the Minister of Labor and Social Policy Denitsa Sacheva.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102205533/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1039    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102205415/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1069

"Workers from businesses closed from January 1 to 31 will receive compensation in the amount of 75% of their insurance income. This is more than the previous BGN 24 that we give and is for employees on an 8-hour working day. In practice, the measure means that employers do not owe anything, and their workers receive 75% of their income," said the Prime Minister.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102205415/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1069

As of December 17, 2020, capitalization of the 2019 profit in the banking system, increase in liquidity of the banking system by BGN 7 billion, agreement on a moratorium on bank loan payments for up to 6 months, and establishment of EUR 2 billion swap line with the ECB until end-2020 or as long as necessary among others; source: /web/20201221134035/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

As of 22 December, the loan repayment moratorium remains in effect.    Borrowers are able to negotiate with lenders until 31 March 2021 to delay payments of both interest and the principal for nine months. Those who have already had six months of loan repayment holidays can negotiate three additional months.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102210418/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/972

e.g. regular update on COVID cases, source: /web/20201221140745/https://www.novinite.com/articles/207168/Bulgaria-COVID-19%3A+1739+New+Cases+for+The+Last+24+Hours; vaccination campaign as of December 15, source: /web/20201221140858/https://sofiaglobe.com/2020/12/15/covid-19-in-bulgaria-47-mobile-teams-will-take-part-in-vaccination-campaign/

As of 3 January, the unified information portal remains the official source of information on measures to combat the spread of COVID-19 in Bulgaria (https://coronavirus.bg). The portal provides statistics, news briefings, video materials, and information about COVID-19 in Bulgaria.     An official chatbot of the Council of Ministers of the Republic of Bulgaria is available, which provides real-time official information and news about COVID-19 through Viber.     The ViruSafe mobile app is available, which gives users the ability to track their symptoms and health status daily. This information gives the Ministry of Health a good overview of the spread of the pandemic. Users can also voluntarily share their location to enable institutions to act accordingly, in case of an emergency.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214232020/https://virusafe.info/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102214833/https://coronavirus.bg/

People having symptoms and meet specific criteria (e.g. key workers, admitted to hospital, contact with known case, returned from oversees); source:  /web/20201221124307/https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/covid-19-testing-policy?stackMode=absolute&time=2020-12-20&country=®ion=World

As of 3 January, testing procedures depend on whether the individual is a first- or second-line contact person, suffers from a chronic illness, falls into the risk category of people over 60, is a medical professional, and has symptoms.     Testing for coronavirus is performed at the discretion of the regional health inspectorate, the medical institution where the patient is hospitalized or the relevant medical person in the designated places for examination and diagnosis (based on symptoms) or with a referral (can be issued electronically or on paper) by a general practitioner.    A referral for a PCR test will also be issued to individuals who test positive for a rapid antigen test performed by an authorized medical care provider.    Optional testing can be done in a private laboratory.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102215235/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/kontaktno-litse
Comprehensive contact tracing (all cases); source: /web/20201221194444/https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/covid-contact-tracing?stackMode=absolute&time=2020-12-06&country=®ion=World

As of 3 January, all close contacts in a confirmed case of COVID-19, at the discretion of an epidemiologist from the regional health inspectorate, are placed under quarantine at home or elsewhere for accommodation and medical supervision for 10-day period, as of the last contact with the sick person. The monitoring of the health condition of each contact person is performed by the general practitioner or the respective regional health inspection.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102215235/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/kontaktno-litse
Required in all public spaces; source: /web/20201221125649/https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/face-covering-policies-covid?stackMode=absolute&country=®ion=World

On 22 December, order RD-01-718 went into effect. Order RD-01-675 also remains in effect.    When serving customers directly, requiring a distance of less than 1.5 meters, the use of a face mask or safety helmet is mandatory. Customer service without a face mask or safety helmet is allowed when mechanical partitions made of glass or other transparent material are provided, allowing wet cleaning or disinfection.    All persons, when they are in open public places, where there is a crowd of people and impossibility to observe a physical distance of 1.5 m, are obliged to have a protective face mask for single or repeated use or other means of covering nose and mouth (including towel, scarf, helmet, etc.), which are used according to the recommendations in the order.    All persons when in closed public places, including means of public transport, medical and health establishments, pharmacies, opticians, national centers for public health, administrative institutions and other places where they are served or citizens have access to railway and bus stations, airports, metro stations, shops, churches, monasteries, temples, museums, etc., must have a protective face mask for single or multiple use or other means covering the nose and mouth (including a towel, scarf, helmet, etc.), which are used according to the recommendations in the order.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102180723/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

On 27 December, the immunization campaign against COVID-19 in Bulgaria began.    The Minister of Health was the first Bulgarian to be vaccinated against coronavirus infection.     163 medical staff from 12 hospitals in Sofia also received the vaccine. Another 440 medics will be immunized in the coming days.    Apart from Sofia, the immunization campaign against COVID-19 in the country started simultaneously in Plovdiv and Burgas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103050522/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1058

On 31 December, the first stage of the vaccination against COVID-19 in Ruse region was successfully completed. 200 doctors, nurses, paramedics and other first-line health personnel in the fight against the disease received the first dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine against coronavirus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103050801/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1080

FBiH (24 Nov):  schools closed (online classes only)    Brcko District (22 Nov):  all schools closed, classes to be held online; kindergartens to remain open;    RS:  schools are to remain open and the academic year is ongoing in the RS; shortened duration of lessons; schools instructed to ensure social distancing and protective measures for students and teachers    https://web.archive.org/web/20200829154713/http://www.ohr.int/report-on-measures-and-orders-adopted-during-the-pandemic-of-covid-19-in-bih/
No policy updates found.

Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina:  Night clubs and discos will remain closed until further notice. Restaurants are allowed to remain open until 11 p.m. All services must take additional hygiene measures and continuously disinfect them. From 5.11.2020, all legal persons, i.e. companies, in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina are obliged to set flexible working hours in the work processes they perform and, where possible, to introduce teleworking.     Republika Srpska  All legal entities, i.e. companies, and public administration are invited to organise the work as a teleworking wherever possible. Opening hours for catering establishments are from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m., with live music prohibited. A minimum of 10 m2 of space must be available for each table with a maximum of 4 people. The opening hours of gambling operators (casinos, vending machines and similar ones) must be reduced to 10 p.m. The so-called "drugstores" (small grocery stores), which are usually open 24H, are only allowed to sell counters after 10 p.m. All shops and businesses must take additional hygiene measures and continuously disinfect them.    Brko District  From 7.12.2020, opening hours of catering establishments, fitness centres, gambling operators, sports schools are limited to 7 p.m.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html
No policy updates found.

Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina:   Public gatherings of more than 30 people outdoors and indoors are prohibited. Parliament's sittings are excluded from this. Exceptionally, no more than 70 people may be present in theatres and cinemas. Organizers are obliged to register all planned events with the cantonal Ministry of Health. Competition activities for sports clubs and athletes may only take place without an audience.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html    Republika Srpska:   All public gatherings with more than 50 people are prohibited.  All private gatherings (weddings, baptisms and birthday parties, family meetings, etc.) with more than 10 people are prohibited.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html    Brcko District: On 3 November, public gatherings in closed spaces were banned.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102174538/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/bosniaandherzegovina/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.2+Physical+distancing&Type=Section    (22 Nov) religious gatherings (funerals, holidays) as well as weddings limited to 30 persons.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200829154713/http://www.ohr.int/report-on-measures-and-orders-adopted-during-the-pandemic-of-covid-19-in-bih/
No policy updates found.

I believe previous coders misinterpret it as of "public gathering"  Various entities in Bosnia and Herzegovina issued separate policies.  Republika Srpska: On 21 October, some of the existing measures were reinforced and expanded (forbidden public gatherings in groups of more than 50 people, private and family gatherings in groups of more than 10 people, live music in hospitality facilities)  Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina: Large gatherings are prohibited (on a similar scale), but I did not find policies specific to "private gatherings".  Brcko District: All public gatherings and unofficial gatherings over 20 people were banned (since 20 July). On 3 November, public gatherings in closed spaces were banned, while the wearing of masks was made mandatory in open spaces for people in groups of two or more.   Sarajevo Canton: limits to the number of people gathering (maximum 60 people in open and 30 in closed spaces) since 15 Oct.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102160920/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/bosniaandherzegovina/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.2+Physical+distancing&Type=Section

Internal movement remains allowed. However:  The departure of citizens of the Republic of Belarus and foreigners permanently residing in the country through functioning ground checkpoints is temporarily suspended (with no ending date announced), with the exception of certain cases. Aviation checkpoints, however, will not be affected by this restriction.  Restrictions on entry for foreigners through ground checkpoints remain in effect. In addition, incoming foreigners over six years old will need medical documents confirming a negative PCR test for COVID-19.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201228093903/https://gpk.gov.by/news/gpk/78840/

Internal movement remains allowed, however, exiting the country via its land borders remains restricted for Belarusian nationals as coded in the last entry.    Otherwise: No update in policy to be found on the official governemental website as well as Belarus' specific Covid portal:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111102447/http://stopcovid.belta.by/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111102756/https://www.belarus.by/en

The land border crossings and railroad border crossings for regular border traffic for entry into Belarus for third-country nationals remain closed. This concerns entry by land from the countries Lithuania, Latvia, Poland and Ukraine. Entry via airports is possible, including 10-day isolation, etc. as mentioned in earlier coding entries.    NOTE – restriction on country exit:  The departure of citizens of the Republic of Belarus and foreigners permanently residing in the country through functioning ground checkpoints is temporarily suspended (with no ending date announced), with the exception of certain cases. No new income support announced. Also, Prime Minister Roman Golovchenko said that the government did not see a slowdown in economic activity in Belarus amidst the second wave of COVID-19 and the social commitments of the state were not only fulfilled, but also over-fulfilled as the average salary reached Br1,300.     “The 8.9% increase in real household income is another testimony to the efficient economic performance,”    “Despite the difficult situation our economy is performing quite well, much better than the economies of many of our neighbors, including the economically stronger ones. According to preliminary estimates, our gross domestic product this year will be at least as big as 99% of last year's. This is the main economic outcome. It is very encouraging that the manufacturing industry has bounced back in recent months,”    “Even when the whole world is struggling through the coronavirus second wave, we do not see a slowdown in economic activity in our country so far,”    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228095057/https://eng.belta.by/economics/view/pm-no-economic-slowdown-in-belarus-amidst-coronavirus-second-wave-136198-2020/    Considering the official stand of the Belarus' government regarding Covid-19, new financial/economic/fiscal measures seem unlikely within the upcoming months at least.

The Ministry of Health is launching a campaign "New Year - Home Holiday" aimed at holding safe New Year holidays.  The purpose of the pre-holiday campaign is to convince the public of the need to comply with safety measures during the COVID-19 pandemic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228095550/https://www.belta.by/society/view/minzdrav-zapuskaet-aktsiju-novyj-god-domashnij-prazdnik-421644-2020/

Specific campaing regarding the festive period still running. Also:    Belarus has a dedicated "Covid Stop" website in place (http://stopcovid.belta.by), hosting various information regarding issues of health, isolation, treatment, etc., which is why I decided to lift the level to a permanent "2".

Comprehensive testing remains in place. As of 5 January a total of over 4 million tests to detect the new coronavirus have been done in Belarus. Also, Belarus lately bought another 30k test kits from Russia:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111105312/https://eng.belta.by/society/view/batch-of-russian-covid-19-test-systems-delivered-to-belarus-136401-2021/

Comprehensive contact tracing seems to remain in place as I was unable to find information saying otherwise on either the official governemental website or Belarus' specific Covid portal:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111102447/http://stopcovid.belta.by/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111102756/https://www.belarus.by/en
No vaccine available

No vaccine available, however, Belarus will start administering the Sputnik V coronavirus vaccine to its citizens in January, Healthcare Minister Dmitry Pinevich told reporters on the 21st of December:    “The first batch of the vaccine will arrive in January. We will start the vaccination program in January,” Dmitry Pinevich said.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228100851/https://eng.belta.by/society/view/belarus-to-start-covid-vaccinations-in-january-136062-2020/

“A new stage starts in Belarus today with mass vaccinations against COVID-19. Medical staff and  teachers, will be the first to get vaccinated. Vaccination will be entirely voluntary,” Belarus Health Minister Dmitry Pinevich was quoted as saying in a statement issued by his ministry and Russian health authorities.    Unable to find evidence regarding funding so have recorded government funded for now, as vaccine is voluntary and only available to certain groups, suggesting that it couldn't be purchased privately (individually funded)          https://web.archive.org/web/20210104125657/https://apnews.com/article/belarus-coronavirus-pandemic-latin-america-auto-racing-glance-russia-fcddcc286f8295421c0ff301c242dad0

Public events will be banned. Exceptions are made for religious services (for up to 50 people), funerals attended by family and close friends, parliamentary assemblies and political demonstrations.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201220075316/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/das-bag/aktuell/medienmitteilungen.msg-id-81582.html

B: Pfizer/BioNTech    First canton (Lucerne) launches vaccination campaign on December 23, starting with vulnerable residents over 65. In the first phase, individual cantons can begin the first vaccinations for people in vulnerable groups on a step-by-step basis. Vaccinations will take place in specific settings such as old people’s and care homes. As of the 18th of December, all bars, restaurants, zoos, museums, swimming pools and other indoor sports facilities will be closed. Shops and services can remain open if they ensure there is only 1 customer per 15 square metres.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210101121028/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/measures-adopted-by-the-czech-government-against-coronavirus-180545/

The office hours of public authorities/institution will be reduced to the minimum.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210101121028/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/measures-adopted-by-the-czech-government-against-coronavirus-180545/

From the 27th of December, public gatherings will be limited to two people. Fifteen people maximum may attend weddings, funerals and entry into a registered partnership.   For church and religious gatherings, the permitted capacity of churches and prayer rooms is reduced to a maximum of 10% of the seating capacities.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210101121028/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/measures-adopted-by-the-czech-government-against-coronavirus-180545/

This will amount to 400 CZK per employee, applied retrospectively from the 14th of October 2020 to 10th January 2021. The first call of the subsidy will amount to 2.5 billion crowns.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210109194821/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/government-approves-further-aid-for-closed-premises--wants-to-extend-easier-administration-of-social-benefits-during-pandemic-185930/

The vaccine used currently is the Pfizer/BioNTech inoculation.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210101213613/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/infection-and-general-measures/when-we-will-have-vaccine

New Lockdown in place, starting on December 15th, provisional running until January 10th.    Contacts in schools, too, are to be drastically reduced between 16 December 2020 and 10 January  2021. During this period, children should be kept at home wherever possible. For this reason, all  schools will be closed or waive the obligation to attend during this period. Emergency childcare  services will be provided and remote learning offered. Special arrangements can be made for final  year classes. Nurseries will proceed similarly. Additional options will be created for parents to take  paid leave to look after their children during this period    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214202434/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1827686/e97802de12b5f6e60f41b73234e618b7/2020-12-14-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1

Measures in place for schools and nurseries will remain in effect, extended to the end of January.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210106175200/https://www.dw.com/en/coronavirus-germany-extends-covid-lockdown-until-january-31/a-56134498

New Lockdown in place, starting on December 15th, provisional running until January 10th.    Retail shops will close from 16 December 2020 until 10 January 2021, with the exception of  grocery stores, open-air food markets, direct marketers of food products, food collection and delivery services, beverage shops, health food shops, specialist baby shops, pharmacies, medical supply stores, drugstores, opticians, hearing aid shops, petrol stations, garages, bicycle workshops, banks and savings banks, post offices, dry cleaning services, launderettes, newsagents, pet supply shops, animal feed shops, the sale of Christmas trees and wholesalers. The sale in grocery stores of non-food products that are not related to daily needs can also be restricted and must on no account be extended. There will be a blanket ban on the sale of fireworks before New Year’s Eve this year.    Businesses offering personal care services such as hairdressers, beauty salons, masseurs, tattoo  parlours and similar establishments will be closed, because physical proximity is unavoidable in these professions. Necessary medical treatments, such as physiotherapy, occupational therapy and speech therapy, as well as podiatry and chiropody, will still be permitted.    Employers are urgently requested to explore the possibility of either closing workplaces  completely holidays or offering employees generous opportunities to work from home from  16 December 2020 to 10 January 2021 in order to implement the principle of “We are staying at  home” throughout Germany.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214202434/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1827686/e97802de12b5f6e60f41b73234e618b7/2020-12-14-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1

New Lockdown in place, starting on December 15th, provisional running until January 10th.    A nationwide ban on all gatherings will be in force on New Year’s Eve and New Year’s Day.  Fireworks will also be banned in highly frequented areas to be defined by the municipalities. There will be a blanket ban on the sale of fireworks before New Year’s Eve this year and a general recommendation not to let off any fireworks, also because of the high risk of injury and the fact that the health system is already under considerable pressure.    Church services and religious gatherings in synagogues and mosques are only possible under the  following conditions: the minimum distance of 1.5 metres must be maintained, the wearing of a face mask is mandatory even when seated, congregational singing is prohibited. For gatherings where the number of visitors expected could lead to capacity being exceeded, a registration requirement must be introduced. In addition, in the coming days talks will take place within and with the religious communities to determine appropriate regulations for religious gatherings in light of the developments in infection rates.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214202434/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1827686/e97802de12b5f6e60f41b73234e618b7/2020-12-14-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1

New Lockdown in place, starting on December 15th, provisional running until January 10th.    Private gatherings with friends, relatives and acquaintances will continue to be limited to a  maximum of 5 individuals from a total of two households. Children up to the age of 14 are not  included in this figure.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214202434/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1827686/e97802de12b5f6e60f41b73234e618b7/2020-12-14-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1

From the 5th of January, private meetings with one other person not living in the same household are permitted (previously a maximum of 5 from 2 households.)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210106175200/https://www.dw.com/en/coronavirus-germany-extends-covid-lockdown-until-january-31/a-56134498

New Lockdown in place, starting on December 15th, provisional running until January 10th.    Rail passengers who have to travel despite restrictions are to be offered a reliable means of traveling safely and with plenty of space. For this purpose, the possibility of reserving seats should be limited.   No specific restrictions, however, the government recommends avoiding using any form of transport and mobility if not urgently required.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214202434/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1827686/e97802de12b5f6e60f41b73234e618b7/2020-12-14-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1

New Lockdown in place, starting on December 15th, provisional running until January 10th.    The Federal Government and the Länder urgently appeal to all citizens to avoid all non-essential  movement and recommend to stay at home.    Individual federal states also impose specific exit restrictions. For example, in the southern states in particular, leaving the home is only permitted if there are valid reasons for doing so (sports, shopping, doctor's appointments, etc.). Local night-time curfew restrictions apply, which generally prohibit leaving the home except in emergencies.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214202434/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1827686/e97802de12b5f6e60f41b73234e618b7/2020-12-14-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1    https://web.archive.org/web/20201218085536/https://www.corona-katastrophenschutz.bayern.de/faq/index.php    https://web.archive.org/web/20201218085159/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-massnahmen-1734724

New Lockdown in place, starting on December 15th, provisional running until January 10th.    The Federal Government and the Länder urgently appeal to all citizens to avoid all non-essential  travel within and outside Germany between now and 10 January.    Individual federal states also impose specific exit restrictions. For example, in Mecklenburg Vorpommer, travel from other german states is currently not allowed (with exceptions).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214202434/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1827686/e97802de12b5f6e60f41b73234e618b7/2020-12-14-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1    https://web.archive.org/web/20201218085957/https://www.regierung-mv.de/service/Corona-FAQs/Tourismus-und-Reisen/

From the 5th of January, residents in hotspot districts (more than 200 per 100,000 cases) are not permitted to travel more than 15 km from their town without a valid reason. Day trips are not classified a valid reason.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210106175200/https://www.dw.com/en/coronavirus-germany-extends-covid-lockdown-until-january-31/a-56134498

New Lockdown in place, starting on December 15th, provisional running until January 10th.    For Germany, travel restrictions apply for entry from a large number of countries. These are issued by the Federal Ministry of the Interior, Building and Community (...)     In principle, entry is possible from:            - EU member states states associated with Schengen: Iceland, Norway, Switzerland and Liechtenstein the United Kingdom;  - Other countries, from which entry is possible due to the epidemiological situation assessment by the EU.  - Entry from other countries is only possible in exceptional cases and is conditional on there being an urgent Need."    Online entry registration is obligatory for travellers entering Germany from high-risk areas abroad, and that quarantine is mandatory for a period of 10 days following return. Quarantine can only be ended with a negative test, which can be taken on the 5th day after entry at the earliest.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201129121721/https://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/en/coronavirus/2317268    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214202434/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1827686/e97802de12b5f6e60f41b73234e618b7/2020-12-14-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1

The measures mean that some sectors of the economy will still have to face significant  restrictions on their business operations in the coming year. The Federal Government will therefore  continue to provide financial support for the affected companies, self-employed individuals and selfemployed members of the independent professions. The improved interim financial help III package, which envisages subsidies for fixed costs, is available to this end. With improved conditions, in particular a higher monthly subsidy of up to a maximum of 500,000 euro for companies directly and indirectly affected by the closures, the Federal Government is doing what it can to safeguard businesses and employment.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214202434/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1827686/e97802de12b5f6e60f41b73234e618b7/2020-12-14-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1

Individuals travelling from certain countries, such as the UK, are banned from entering Denmark.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210108132907/https://coronasmitte.dk/en/entry-into-denmark/persons-arriving-in-denmark-from-the-uk

Citizens of all countries have been banned from entering Denmark from January 9 until January 18, as part of the country’s efforts to prevent the further spread of the Coronavirus pandemic, precisely due to the new mutation of the virus found in Britain and some other countries.    In addition, Denmark’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs has urged all its citizens to avoid travelling to other countries due to the disease’s rapid spread, SchengenVisaInfo.com reports.    The latest announcement of Denmark’s authorities clarified that the whole world would be “sharpened from being orange to red.”    Denmark’s Foreign Minister Jeppe Kofod has stressed that the new mutations of the Coronavirus pandemic, spread in several other countries pose a significant risk that Denmark’s infection rates may escalate.      “The safety and security of Danes is the government’s priority. We can see the finish line. The vaccine is here. We must not stumble on the run-up stretch. Not least in the light of the new mutations, we will have to – all of us – make an extra effort. And today’s package of travel initiatives is an expression of that,” says Foreign Minister Jeppe Kofod.    Recently Denmark announced plans to impose a digital ‘vaccine passport’ which would permit all vaccinated citizens against COVID-19 disease to travel to countries which oblige citizens to have such a document, in order to be able to enter these countries.    According to the Danish Health Ministry, the ‘vaccine passport will be rolled out in early 2021,” and all those vaccinated would be eligible to obtain the document through Denmark’s public health website.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111123210/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/denmark-temporarily-bans-from-entering-citizens-of-all-countries/    From 5:00 p.m. on 9 January 2021 through 7 February 2021, Denmark has instituted a flight ban on the transport of passengers, including Danish citizens, who are unable to present a negative COVID-19 test taken within 24 hours before departure.   https://archive.vn/eOv2R

To prevent the spreading of the British and South African mutations of COVID-19, the Danish government has imposed a flight ban on transportation of passengers from the entire world who are unable to present a negative COVID-19 test.  The ban will allow passenger flights only under the condition, that all passengers onboard the airplane have been tested negative for COVID-19 within 24 hours of boarding the plane. Children under the age of 12 will be excluded from the test requirement  http://web.archive.org/web/20210115173415/https://coronasmitte.dk/en/entry-into-denmark/regarding-passengers-travelling-to-denmark-by-air

The compensation schemes for salary and revenue loss will continue until 31 January. COVID-19 testing to be stepped up in Greater Copenhagen  Testing in Greater Copenhagen has been stepped up and will be intensified in the  weeks ahead.    Additional mobile testing units will be made available locally to ensure access  to testing for as many people as possible. Based on the spread of infections  and an ongoing dialogue with the authorities of the municipalities comprised  by the measures, the mobile testing units will be deployed in locations with  the greatest need.    The intensified testing scheme comprises all citizens.  Announcements will be made locally as to where and when the new testing  opportunities will be available. People are urged to await such  announcements before booking tests unless the test is booked for other  specific reasons such as mild symptoms and test slots for close contacts.  Further, particular efforts will be targeted at young citizens in Greater  Copenhagen who typically account for the highest infection rates. All young  people aged 15 to 25 in Greater Copenhagen are encouraged to take a test.  Announcements will be made locally as to where and when the testing of  those aged 15 to 25 is carried out.          https://web.archive.org/web/20210106161216/https://coronasmitte.dk/en/-/media/mediefiler/corona/hovedstaden/intensified-efforts-to-curb-the-spread-of-covid19-in-greater-copenhagen.pdf?la=en&hash=A35282D491A09102D5284D586457138D5DA61D3B

Persons aged 12 and over must wear a bandage or visor in the following places:  In public transport, etc., including in trains, buses, taxis, ferries, as well as at station areas and stops, etc.  At restaurants where food, drinks or tobacco are served for consumption at the point of sale.  In the retail trade, including in department stores, grocery stores, department stores, department stores, department stores, bazaars, arcades, places that sell food and beverages that are not consumed at the point of sale (take-away), etc.  In premises where cultural, sports and association activities are carried out, including museums, sports halls, fitness centers, art galleries, venues, libraries, cultural centers, zoos, cinemas, theaters, association rooms, etc.  In rooms where the Danish National Church and denominations outside the Danish National Church carry out activities.  In job centers and in citizen service centers.  At institutions that carry out preparatory education, youth education, Danish education for adult foreigners, etc., adult and continuing education, higher education, Folkeuniversitetet, day colleges, evening schools, music and culture schools, driving schools that carry out theory teaching, and folk high schools, etc.  Public and private hospitals and clinics, clinics, etc. in the practice sector, municipal health services, municipal and private care centers and nursing homes, relief places as well as a number of placements and housing facilities in the social area.  During the conduct of practical driving tests, indicative health driving tests and at final tests in driving when one is in a vehicle with others.    Thus, there is no general requirement to wear a bandage or visor in all rooms to which the public has access.    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201124101122/https://coronasmitte.dk/mundbind-og-visir

In a government announcement on the 9th of December, it was announced that all educational establishments across Estonia will be closed until 2021.   In person learning is allowed for students with special educational needs, personal consultations, olympiads, internships and examinations with measures of social distancing in place.   Kindergartens and childcare will remain open.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201209134400/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-imposes-additional-restrictions-both-ida-viru-county-and-across-estonia-prevent

The government approved the extension of the current education restrictions to and including the 10th of January.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210101134054/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-imposes-restrictions-similar-ida-virumaa-harju-county-and-agreed-additional-support

From the 12th of December, in Ida-Viru County, entertainment and accommodation facilities, museums and exhibitions must be closed to visitors. All sports facilities must be closed. This does not apply to professional sports activities. All sales and service halls of catering companies must be closed. Food takeaway and related courier service will be allowed.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201210173303/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-approved-new-national-restrictions-and-restrictions-ida-viru-county

Restrictions are expanded in Harju County and Ida-Viru County from the 28th of December. All entertainment services must close. All catering company premises are closed to customers, however food takeaway and delivery services are permitted. All sports facilities must be closed to visitors. However this does not apply to professional athletes or those with special needs.   Indoor youth work, hobby activities, further education/informal education is no longer permitted.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210101134054/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-imposes-restrictions-similar-ida-virumaa-harju-county-and-agreed-additional-support

From the 12th of December in the Ida-Viru County, both outdoor and indoor public meetings and events, including conferences, theatre performances, concerts, and cinema screenings are not allowed.   Churches and other religious venues may continue to operate at 50% capacity with 2+2 distancing.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201210173303/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-approved-new-national-restrictions-and-restrictions-ida-viru-county

In Harju County and Ida-Viru County, public meetings and events are prohibited. This includes conferences, theatre performances, indoor cinema viewing, museum and exhibition viewing.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210101134054/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-imposes-restrictions-similar-ida-virumaa-harju-county-and-agreed-additional-support

From the 14th of December, hobby education, hobby activities and sports activities for young people and adults will be suspended for three weeks. Only individual activities/learning/sports offered remotely or outdoors are allowed.   The restrictions do not apply to professional athletes.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201209134400/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-imposes-additional-restrictions-both-ida-viru-county-and-across-estonia-prevent

From the 24th of December, a 50% of maximum capacity requirement for religious services will apply nationally.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210101134054/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-imposes-restrictions-similar-ida-virumaa-harju-county-and-agreed-additional-support

In Harju County and Ida-Viru Count, from the 28th of December a maximum of 10 people can take part in meetings outdoors.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210101134054/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-imposes-restrictions-similar-ida-virumaa-harju-county-and-agreed-additional-support

The Estonian vaccination drive began on 27th of December. Healthcare workers (group A) are the first to be vaccinated, using the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210101212336/https://news.err.ee/1220851/over-200-health-care-workers-receive-covid-19-vaccination-on-first-day

In Helsinki, upper secondary schools (general upper secondary schools and vocational education) have transferred to distance learning as of 3 December 2020. These learning institutions will still provide face-to-face instruction that is deemed essential. For example, contact teaching will be offered to students with disabilities that are receiving special needs education and to students who need individual support for various reasons. Distance learning will continue at these schools until 10 January 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104175356/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/coronavirus-en/childhood-and    In the rest of the country, schools remain open but with social distancing measures in place.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104175432/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/questions-and-answers

No change in policy. The closing of Helsinki's upper secondary schools has been extended until 31 January.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210108140940/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/coronavirus-en/childhood-and

Helsinki:  Upper secondary schools (general upper secondary schools and vocational education) have transferred to distance learning as of 3 December 2020. These learning institutions will still provide face-to-face instruction that is deemed essential. For example, contact teaching will be offered to students with disabilities that are receiving special needs education and to students who need individual support for various reasons. Distance learning will continue at these schools until 31 January 2021.    A mask recommendation has been issued for the area’s lower secondary schools (grades 6-9). The cities will provide masks for this purpose, but students are also free to use their own.    Daycare centres and pre-primary education are still open, with due regard for the necessary safety measures. Daycare centre staff are encouraged to wear masks indoors whenever possible. Early childhood education employees who travel to several locations in their work, for example, daycare assistants, replacements, directors, trainees and interns are in particular asked to observe this mask recommendation. Parents and guardians of children in daycare and pre-primary education are asked to wear masks when they pick up and drop off their children and limit the time they spend indoors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115123931/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/coronavirus-en/childhood-and

In general, working from home is recommended and workplaces remain open. In Helsinki, public spaces have been closed, which means the closure of some sectors, including all urban indoor sports facilities, cultural centers, museums, youth facilities and the zoo. This measure is in place from 30 Nov 2020 until 31 Jan 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210108142952/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/korona-fi/koronaneuvonta/voimassa-olevat-suositukset-ja-rajoitukset

In general, working from home is recommended and workplaces remain open. In Helsinki, public spaces have been closed, which means the closure of some sectors, including all urban indoor sports facilities, cultural centers, museums, youth facilities and the zoo. This measure is in place from 30 Nov 2020 until 31 Jan 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210108142952/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/korona-fi/koronaneuvonta/voimassa-olevat-suositukset-ja-rajoitukset

Generally open across the country:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115124620/https://avi.fi/usein-kysyttya-koronaviruksesta#accordion-UVp6uI6UjCaV    But public spaces are closed in Helsinki until 31st January:  All customer spaces open to the public will be closed. This means, for example, all urban indoor sports facilities, cultural centers, museums and youth facilities. Workers' colleges will be suspended. Korkeasaari Zoo will also close.?  Facilities for social and health services, early childhood education, basic education and basic secondary education will be kept open. Also, for example, the necessary use of transaction machines in libraries and the distribution of face masks to the needy will continue. Cities define facilities that provide essential services that are kept open in a limited and safe manner.  The coordination group recommends private actors to close the corresponding sports and leisure facilities.?  Libraries offer a limited service  Valid from 30.11.2020 to 31.01.2021.    Half of the customer seats in restaurants serving mainly alcoholic beverages may be used, 3/4 non-alcoholic restaurants. The restriction is valid on 28.2.2021. until current  https://web.archive.org/web/20210108142952/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/korona-fi/koronaneuvonta/voimassa-olevat-suositukset-ja-rajoitukset    Teleworking is widely recommended  Teleworking is recommended for all those tasks where it is possible to do it, taking into account the work tasks. In addition, work arrangements will be promoted to reduce close contacts and other risk factors in the workplace.  In private and public sector workplaces, it is recommended that all those present present use face masks indoors at all encounters and when moving around the workplace. The use of a face mask is not required for persons who, due to their state of health, cannot use the mask. A person's own statement of the matter is considered sufficient.  The recommendation is valid until further notice.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210108142952/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/korona-fi/koronaneuvonta/voimassa-olevat-suositukset-ja-rajoitukset

The strictest regional policy is that public events and gatherings are only allowed up to 10 people, which means that, in practice, public events are not able to take place. No restrictions on private events.  Regional government agencies' regulations on restrictions on gatherings do not apply to private events, such as weddings organized by private individuals. Private events are all private events that are not open to the public, such as weddings, funerals, christenings, birthday parties, and private evenings. However, the government recommends that general guidelines on hygiene, safety distances, and other arrangements to prevent coronavirus infections be followed at these events as well.    Public events are allowed in as much as the meeting regulations allow, so those areas whereby 10 people maximum can meet (see C4) are consequentially unable to hold events. Hence 2T. In Helinki, correspondingly, all indoor and outdoor public events and general meetings are prohibited for a limited period of time, allowing up to 10 people to attend essential public events and meetings, provided that safety can be ensured in accordance with the instructions issued by the Ministry of Education and Culture and THL on 21.9.2020.?  [https://web.archive.org/web/20210108143432/https://avi.fi/usein-kysyttya-koronaviruksesta#item-FkUhWGKAqmTQ-33782706]  https://web.archive.org/web/20210108142952/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/korona-fi/koronaneuvonta/voimassa-olevat-suositukset-ja-rajoitukset
