According to the government FAQ:     Is travel within Finland allowed?    Travel within Finland is allowed as long as health and safety guidelines relating to coronavirus are observed.    All travel must be avoided when ill. During travel, it is important to observe good hand and respiratory hygiene. It is important to avoid unnecessary physical contact Tourism businesses must pay particular attention to cleaning, preparedness planning and training of staff.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104175432/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/questions-and-answers

Non-Schengen: Entry into Finland is restricted. Return travel and essential traffic are permitted. These measures will remain in force until 12 January 2012.     Schengen: Restrictions on internal border traffic are in force for traffic between Finland and Austria, Belgium, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland, with the exception of leisure boating.    Restrictions have been lifted for traffic arriving in Finland from the Vatican, and for traffic between Finland and Australia, Japan, Rwanda, South Korea, Singapore, Thailand and New Zealand for residents of these countries.    A 10-day period of self-isolation is recommended for travellers arriving in Finland. Travellers can shorten their self-isolation period at their discretion if they take two voluntary COVID-19 tests.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104182727/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/entry-restrictions

Mask use is never mandatory, but now recommended extensively. In the regions where the infection rates are highest, in the so-called "spreading phase" (according to the Finnish classification of regions into 3 types: basic, accelleration, spreading), the recommendation includes:   - Always on public transport including taxis.  - Always in public spaces and events, including schools and educational institutions from year 7 upwards.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210108154838/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/recommendation-on-the-use-of-face-masks-for-citizens

Recommended for the use of a face mask for all people over 15 years of age  In public transport  In public events and facilities such as shops and banks  In city services such as libraries, social and health services, and cultural services  At sports and cultural events  In all leisure facilities  In secondary schools, including high schools, and colleges  In high schools. For high school students, the city offers masks.  Parents in early childhood education facilities, for example when taking and picking up children  For early childhood education staff indoors where possible. The use of the mask is especially recommended for people who travel to different places in their work, such as deputies, daycare assistants, daycare managers, interns and on-the-job learners.  Social and health care personnel in patient and client work  In the workplace for all those present at all encounters and when moving around the workplace. The recommendation applies to both private and public sector jobs.  When applying for a coronavirus test and before obtaining a result, if there is a necessary reason to move outdoors  When arriving in Finland from a risk area and moving from the point of entry to quarantine or if there is a necessary reason to move outside during quarantine.  In other situations where it is not possible to avoid close contact.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201127004315/https://hel.fi/helsinki/korona-fi/koronaneuvonta/voimassa-olevat-suositukset-ja-rajoitukset#matkustus

Finland's vaccination campaign started on 27 December, with front-line ICU healthcare workers in Helsinki being the first recipients of the vaccine.     Vaccination takes place according to vaccine priority groups. These are:   1) healthcare and social welfare workers who examine or directly treat and care for patients with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 disease or who provide other kinds of urgent care, and workers and residents in care homes for older adults;  2) all those 70 years of age and older;   3) persons at high risk for severe COVID-19 disease due to underlying health conditions;   4) other persons than those in priority groups 1–3.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104183537/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/-/1271139/healthcare-and-social-welfare-workers-first-in-line-to-get-authorised-covid-19-vaccines-on-voluntary-basis

A,B,C as per: https://web.archive.org/web/20210115143227/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/vaccines-and-coronavirus/vaccination-order-and-at-risk-groups-for-covid-19 Vaccines on order: BioNTech – Pfizer (Comirnaty-vaccin) Moderna AstraZeneca Curevac Jansen Group Sanofi-GSK Novavax http://web.archive.org/web/20210115143749/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/vaccines-and-coronavirus/arranging-covid-19-vaccinations-in-finland  Note, that all are planned to be vaccinated, but it is currently only rolled out for two groups: According to a Government Decree (22 December 2020), the vaccinations are first offered to social and health care professionals who treat COVID-19 patients and to people who work and live in nursing homes or housing services for the elderly. Most of these vaccinations will be carried out in January–February 2021.   The vaccine will then be offered to elderly persons and to those with diseases that predispose them to severe coronavirus disease. After that, the vaccine will be offered to the rest of the population. It is still unclear when the vaccine can be offered to everyone willing to be vaccinated because the schedule mainly depends on the marketing authorisations and the availability of the vaccines.

No policy changes. Current situation in more detail:    •	Broad restrictions on non-essential travel from many countries outside the European Union, including the United States, remain in place. The French government has defined essential travel as entry by French citizens, residents of France, all foreign (including United States citizen) students (with appropriate visa or residence permit), and spouses and children of French citizens.  •	In rare cases, the French government will consider allowing travel in humanitarian situations and in cases of business activity important to the French economy, and have announced a program to allow unmarried couples to reunite.    https://archive.vn/jGRh1#selection-2331.0-2331.47    •	France announced they would be restricting travel from the UK from 00:00 (CET) on 20 December. Travel restriction apply to all air, car, ferry and train passengers. If you are due to travel to France please contact your travel operator. Until at least 6 January, only the following categories of people will be authorised to travel to France from the UK:  1.	French nationals and nationals of the European Area and their spouses and children  2.	British and/or third country nationals who are either habitually resident in France, the European Union or the European Area, or who must travel for certain essential reasons (as specified by the French government)  3.	British or third country nationals travelling for certain exceptional reasons, see the French Embassy London’s list.  •	All travellers from the UK, including children aged 11 and above, will need to present a negative COVID-19 test result, carried out less than 72 hours before departure  •	Please check our COVID-19 advice on things to consider, and be prepared to stay overseas longer than planned  •	Although there is no restriction on travel from most European countries, travel from most non-European countries is subject to entry restrictions  •	Arrivals from the UK will need to complete both a ‘sworn statement’ (déclaration sur l’honneur) form self-certifying they are not suffering from symptoms associated with coronavirus and have not been in contact with confirmed cases in the preceding fortnight, and a signed ‘travel certificate’ (attestation), confirming their reason for travel. These can be found on the French government’s website.    https://archive.vn/3mbzC

La capacité de dépistage dans les établissements scolaires sera également augmentée, avec un objectif de 300 000 tests par semaine et des objectifs fixés par académie.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115103746/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    Testing freely available for asymptomatic people who are at particular risk from the disease.  La vaccination est désormais ouverte à l’ensemble des personnes appartenant aux catégories suivantes :  •	Les personnes âgées de plus de 75 ans (à partir de lundi 18 janvier).  •	Les résidents volontaires en EHPAD et USLD, qui sont vaccinés directement dans les établissements.  •	Les personnes âgées séjournant dans les établissements de santé et en services de soins de suite et de réadaptation.  •	Les personnes âgées hébergées en résidences autonomie, résidences services et autres lieux de vie spécialisés, ainsi que dans les foyers de travailleurs migrants.  •	Les personnes en situation de handicap, vulnérables, hébergées en maisons d’accueil spécialisées et foyers d’accueils médicalisés.  •	Les professionnels de santé (et autres professionnels des établissements de santé et des établissements médico-sociaux intervenant auprès de personnes vulnérables), les aides à domicile intervenant auprès de personnes âgées et handicapées vulnérables et les sapeurs-pompiers, lorsqu’ils ont plus de 50 ans ou présentent une ou plusieurs des comorbidités suivantes :  o	L’obésité (IMC>30),  o	La BPCO et l’insuffisance respiratoire,  o	L’hypertension artérielle compliquée,  o	L’insuffisance cardiaque,  o	Le diabète (de type 1 et de type 2)  o	L’insuffisance rénale chronique,  o	Les cancers et maladies hématologiques malignes actifs et de moins de 3 ans  o	Le fait d’avoir une transplantation d’organe solide ou de cellules souches hématopoïétiques,  o	La trisomie 21.  •	Les personnes ayant une pathologie qui les expose à un très haut risque face à la Covid-19 disposant d’une ordonnance médicale pour se faire vacciner prioritairement.  Les patients particulièrement vulnérables à la Covid concernés sont les suivants :  o	atteints de cancer et de maladies hématologiques malignes en cours de traitement par chimiothérapie  o	atteints de maladies rénales chroniques sévères, dont les patients dialysés  o	transplantés d’organes solides  o	transplantés par allogreffe de cellules souches hématopoïétiques  o	atteints de poly-pathologies chroniques, selon le critère suivant : au moins deux insuffisances d’organes  o	atteints de certaines maladies rares (voire liste sur le site du ministère de la santé)  o	atteints de trisomie 21.  Si vous êtes concerné, vous pouvez vous faire vacciner dès à présent dans un des centres de vaccination ouverts.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115113356/https://www.sante.fr/centres-vaccination-covid.html    Testing for people who do not meet these criteria is also available, but at a cost of about EUR 70 to EUR 100. Which however is covered by French Health insurance (“Sécurité Sociale”). So e.g. a US citizen who is not covered by French Health insurance would have to pay for the treatment individually.  https://fr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Further confirmation that testing without symptoms is available (need to get an appointment via a website), but people who do not meet the above mentioned criteria are not considered a priority (implying it may take longer for them to get an appointment).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115121550/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/tests-et-depistage

PARIS (Reuters) - France will start its COVID-19 vaccination programme next Sunday, Health Minister Olivier Veran wrote on his Twitter feed.  https://archive.vn/HrrMw

As of Dec. 31, only 352 people had gotten at least one dose of the vaccine, versus 131,626 in Germany and 944,539 in the U.K., according to data cited by Le Parisien.  https://archive.vn/0E17Q    From 2nd January, people over 50 will begin to be vaccinated (which had previously been planned for February), to speed up the vaccination roll out.  https://archive.vn/R00XW

The HAS (Haute Autorite de Sante = High Authority of Health) recommends first vaccinating the elderly in establishments, in particular EHPADs, as well as the staff working there when they are at risk of developing a severe form of COVID. This represents around 1 million people.    On January 5, 2020, Olivier Véran indicated that firefighters and home helpers over 50 years old will be able to benefit from the injection as priority personnel. "They are also professionals who are in contact with fragile people and who may have to work with the sick," said the minister to justify this decision.  https://archive.vn/a0Ju1

Previously coded policy is still in place in this period. By now, 318.216 have been vaccinated, out of which 10% are residents of care homes. The remainder are caregivers over the age of 50 or with comorbidities, but also firefighters, home helpers over the age of 50 or with comorbidities.  https://archive.vn/J7Rwn    So some members of the following groups have started receiving vaccines:  A Key workers  C Elderly groups  https://archive.vn/R3Ic2    The vaccines that are given are PfizerBiontech and Moderna.  BioNTech-Pfizer's vaccine was approved by the EMA and then by the European Commission on 22 December. On Wednesday 6 January 2021, the European Commission gave the green light to the Covid-19 vaccine developed by the American start-up Moderna, this decision was approved by the High Health Authority on Friday 8 January 2021. To date, two additional vaccines are being evaluated by the EMA following Phase III clinical trials: the AstraZeneca and Janssen laboratories.  https://archive.vn/dNmaS    In addition, from 18 January, people over the age of 75 will be able to get vaccinated as well as people with one of the five pathologies leading to a very high risk of serious form of the disease, regardless of their age.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210113222447/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins    Note that the government has faced a lot of criticism regarding a perceived slowness and overly bureaucratic approach in rolling out the vaccines.  https://archive.vn/R3Ic2    France wants to immunize 1 million people by the end of January but at the current vaccination rate, it will reach that target in late February.  There is also widespread vaccine-scepticism.  https://archive.vn/trhlh    Polls suggest that less than 40% of the population here is planning to take the vaccine.   https://archive.vn/J7Rwn

14. December 2020, The Government with new measures for Christmas    Retailers at Christmas: Businesses should ensure that hand sanitiser is readily available and that stores are kept clean. Signs should be clearly displayed to help customers keep to the recommendations. Staff should use protective gear where necessary. Retailers can help by making face masks available for customers. If retailers cannot limit the number of customers so that the recommended distances can be maintained, then both customers and staff are advised to wear face masks.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201214155432/https://corona.fo/news/748/the-government-with-new-measures-for-christmas?_l=en

14. December 2020, The Government with new measures for Christmas    · Sport: All indoor sporting events should be held without spectators. This applies to both adult and children’s competitions. Coaches and assistants can be present during matches.    · Schools and daycare centres are advised not to hold larger events to which people from outside the institution are usually invited. This includes Christmas celebrations which would normally be attended by parents and other family members. Christmas church services for school pupils and preschool children should not be organised as usual this year      https://web.archive.org/web/20201214155432/https://corona.fo/news/748/the-government-with-new-measures-for-christmas?_l=en

14. December 2020, The Government with new measures for Christmas    · Schools and daycare centres are advised not to hold larger events to which people from outside the institution are usually invited. This includes Christmas celebrations which would normally be attended by parents and other family members. Christmas church services for school pupils and preschool children should not be organised as usual this year.    · Christmas shopping: Special emphasis should be placed on social distancing hand and hygiene and. It is advisable that only one person in the household does the shopping, rather than going several together. It is also advisable to go shopping when there are fewer people.  Face masks are recommended when a lot of people are in a shop. If you have come to the Faroe Islands from abroad, you should not go shopping at all until you have received a negative result from the test that you should take 6 days after arrival.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201214155432/https://corona.fo/news/748/the-government-with-new-measures-for-christmas?_l=en

England enters lockdown on Tuesday 5 January. All schools are closed, except for the children of essential workers, despite all students having attended school on Monday 4th.     Colleges, primary (reception onwards) and secondary schools will remain open for vulnerable children and the children of critical workers. All other children will learn remotely until February half term  Universities- Those students who are undertaking training and study for the specific courses should return to face to face learning as planned and be tested twice, upon arrival or self-isolate for ten days.    All 4 devolved nations now have schools closed, meaning this is a policy that applies generally across the UK now      https://web.archive.org/web/20210106100514/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/national-lockdown-stay-at-home

Under the restrictions introduced for people in Tier 4 areas, non-essential shops, hairdressers, and leisure and entertainment venues must close, with a new “stay at home” message introduced.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201221220505/https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2020/dec/21/covid-tier-4-what-are-the-new-rules-london-south-east-england-christmas

Scots are to be ordered to stay at home amid a fresh Covid-19 lockdown on 5 January. These are the toughest restrictions Scotland has faced since the lockdown of March 2020.  Non essential workplaces closed and people must work from home if possible.    These rules will apply across the Scottish mainland until at least the end of January, and will be kept under review.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104154939/https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-55531069

On Christmas Day, up to three households in tier 2 and 3 will be able to come together. This marks a tightening of the previous policy, under which households were to be allowed five days.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210101072410/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/explainers-55056375

Under Tier 4 restrictions, you must stay at home, and you must not leave your home to travel unless for essential work, education, or other legally permitted reasons    http://web.archive.org/web/20201221220916/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/coronavirus-covid-19-safer-travel-guidance-for-passengers

All devolved nations are under stay at home orders    Scots are to be ordered to stay at home amid a fresh Covid-19 lockdown on 5 January. These are the toughest restrictions Scotland has faced since the lockdown of March 2020.      The new rules - which will be put down in law - mean Scots will only be allowed to leave home for essential purposes, such as shopping for food and medicine, exercise and caring responsibilities.    No limit is to be put on how many times people can go out to exercise, but outdoor meetings are to be limited to a maximum of two people from two households.      These rules will apply across the Scottish mainland until at least the end of January, and will be kept under review.    https://web.archive.org/web/20

Under tier 4 restrictions, people cannot leave home for holidays or stays overnight away from their main home unless permitted by law.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201221220916/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/coronavirus-covid-19-safer-travel-guidance-for-passengers

Scots are to be ordered to stay at home amid a fresh Covid-19 lockdown on 5 January. These are the toughest restrictions Scotland has faced since the lockdown of March 2020. The government has quietly introduced a loophole to its eviction ban that waters down protections for people who lost their jobs during the pandemic.    Ministers on Friday announced that they were extending the ban on bailiff evictions that has been in place since the first lockdown in March, covering most tenants for another six weeks.    But the announcement did not mention a key change snuck out in legislation that will for the first time give landlords the power to evict people for not paying their rent during lockdown.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210115172832/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/eviction-ban-loophole-substantial-arrears-six-months-b1784836.html

The Government of Georgia imposed movement restrictions in major cities between 9 PM and 5 AM. During the restricted time, public and private transportation (including walking) is not permitted, unless it is for an essential need. Also, there is in place a recommendation for people over the age of 70 to remain at home.  Link: https://archive.fo/rII13 and Prevention of Coronavirus Spread in Georgia (archive.fo)

With a few exceptions, Georgia remains closed to foreign travelers. The entry ban for foreign citizens applies to air, land, and sea borders, including foreign citizens who are legal residents of Georgia, or have been living and working in Georgia, or own property or business. Also, there are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/LILgr

Face masks must be worn in all enclosed public spaces, including taxis and public transportation. Violators of face musk rules are subject to a 20 GEL (about 6 USD) fine. There are some exceptions for children under 6, people with disabilities, or who have health problems that prevent them from wearing a face covering.  Link: COVID-19 Information for Georgia | U.S. Embassy in Georgia (archive.fo)

December 27: the first vaccinations will be performed in the reference hospitals of Attica (Attiko, Evangelismos, Sotiria, Thriasio, Asklipieio Voulas).      Source:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210103143553/https://eody.gov.gr/erotiseis-kai-apantiseis-schetika-me-ton-emvoliasmo-gia-ton-koronoio-sars-cov-2/     http://web.archive.org/web/20210103143655/https://news.gtp.gr/2020/12/21/greece-announces-when-general-population-will-receive-covid-19-vaccine/

Vaccinations will take place based on priority groups.     December 30: Greek authorities expect to receive a larger vaccine batch from Pfizer – 83,850 doses.    – Following the vaccination of frontline healthcare workers and vulnerable groups that have priority, the vaccinations of the general population will begin some time during the second ten days of January 2021.     The vaccine for the coronavirus (Covid-19) is expected to be available to Greece’s general population in mid-January, according to General Secretary of Primary Health Care Mario Themistokleous.    Source:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210103143553/https://eody.gov.gr/erotiseis-kai-apantiseis-schetika-me-ton-emvoliasmo-gia-ton-koronoio-sars-cov-2/     http://web.archive.org/web/20210103143655/https://news.gtp.gr/2020/12/21/greece-announces-when-general-population-will-receive-covid-19-vaccine/

The latest update remains that there is an executive order in place, until and including the 31st January 2021, which states:  “It is possible to hold public events within current municipal boundaries with certain restrictions. It is the organizer's responsibility to ensure that there is no participation from people from other municipalities, or that this is encouraged.  Courses can still be run with external teachers, as long as the participants are from the same municipality.”  “There must be a maximum of 100 people for an indoor event, provided that the rules on occupancy in the room itself of a maximum of 50% of what is allowed are also complied with. For outdoor events, there can be a maximum of 250 people.”    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221150605/https://nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/forsamlinger_i_groenland?sc_lang=da

Vaccination Plan:  First, it is planned to vaccinate employees and users of homes for the elderly (and other institutions for the provision of accommodation in the social welfare system) and health workers, then (conditionally speaking, the second phase of vaccination) all persons over 65 and all persons with chronic diseases, and finally (conditionally speaking, the third phase) the entire population.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110040933/https://www.koronavirus.hr/uputa-priprema-za-cijepljenje-protiv-covid-19-884/884    Doses ordered:  Procurement is contracted with several manufacturers and the procedures are still ongoing.  Contracts with four manufacturers have already been concluded.  Under these contracts, we expect a total of 5,600,000 doses of vaccine by the end of 2021.  Considering that all * vaccines are administered in two doses with different intervals, the amount agreed so far is sufficient for vaccination of 2,800,000 inhabitants of the Republic of Croatia.  * except for Janssen vaccine for which there is a possibility of administering 1 dose  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110040933/https://www.koronavirus.hr/uputa-priprema-za-cijepljenje-protiv-covid-19-884/884    de facto capacity and evidence:  First doses of coronavirus vaccine arrive in Croatia  https://www.croatiaweek.com/first-doses-of-coronavirus-vaccine-arrive-in-croatia/    Croatian PM says COVID vaccines will be free  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110181420/https://www.croatiaweek.com/croatian-pm-says-covid-vaccines-will-be-free/

On December 19, economic protections are extended until 01 July.  According to this, the moratorium on loan repayments for families and businesses will be extended unchanged for six months until 1 July. The moratorium will be automatically extended, only those who want to repay their loan despite the moratorium will have to visit their bank, the Prime Minister said.  It also announced that businesses forced to close temporarily as a a cause of disease measures would be supported by the government in December and January by waived and taking over two-thirds of wage costs. In addition to catering, hotels and tourism, the remission of contributions and wage subsidies will be extended to private bus companies that are forced to take a break.  Viktor Orban also said that business taxes for small and medium-sized enterprises and sole proprietors will be cut by half from 1 January. These businesses account for the most jobs and are the most vulnerable during the epidemic, he justified the measure, adding that municipalities of less than 25,000 inhabitants will receive support from the government and the financial situation of larger municipalities will be reviewed individually.  The fourth decision is to help families with children and children with a reduced home improvement loan of up to HUF 6 million with a maximum interest rate of 3 percent. Of this, HUF 3 million is a non-refundable grant, which can be used at the end of the renovation and automatically reduces the amount of the loan, the Prime Minister explained.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219210422/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/cikkek/orban-viktor-kormany-gazdasagvedelmi-akcioterv-kiegesziteserol-rendelkezett

The government announced that from midnight on 24 December until 12 January, Level 5 restrictions (the equivalent of full lockdown) will apply nationally, due to NPHET concerns at the rapid increase in COVID-19 case numbers.    Under normal level 5 restrictions, schools remain open, but the decision was made on 30th December to delay reopening schools for the new term. On the 6th January, it was decided to close all schools, including for students with special needs, for at least three weeks.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201230203846/https://www.irishtimes.com/news/education/schools-welcome-decision-to-close-until-january-11th-1.4447636  http://web.archive.org/web/20210107211029/https://www.gov.ie/en/press-release/11176-minister-foley-confirms-that-schools-will-remain-closed-to-students/

Higher and adult education    Higher, further and adult education should remain primarily online."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210110221430/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/2dc71-level-5/

Particular importance will be placed on vaccinating persons who are in the frontline in the battle against the pandemic. This applies to healthcare workers and others working in emergency departments and intensive care units in hospitals, on COVID-19 wards and wards for patients who have been infected with COVID-19, healthcare workers who perform screening tests in cases of suspected COVID-19 and the staff of nursing and retirement homes. The vaccination of persons living in nursing and retirement homes and old-age wards in hospitals will also have high priority.    There are ten priority groups. The groups with the greatest priority consist of a relatively few number of people; the first five groups are estimated to number around 20,000 persons.    Group 6: Persons aged 60 and older    Group 7: Persons with underlying long-term illnesses    Group 8: Employees of nursery, primary and secondary schools and select groups of social and welfare service workers    Group 9: Persons who are in sensitive circumstances due to their social and economic situation    And finally, Group 10: All others who request vaccination, as determined by the Chief Epidemiologist.    The regulation makes no provision for the COVID-19 vaccination of children born 2006 or later unless such children have an underlying long-term illness and are members of a special risk group.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210103140447/https://www.covid.is/categories/information-on-covid-19-vaccine

Iceland received the first doses of COVID-19 vaccine on December 28 and vaccination began on December 29. At the moment, Iceland is expecting to receive vaccine for at least 30,000 people before the end of March.  COVID-19 vaccination is optional and free of charge in Iceland. Vaccines are being administered according to priority groups defined by health authorities, though the Chief Epidemiologist may grant exceptions to that order. The first to be vaccinated were frontline healthcare workers and nursing home residents. According to the current vaccination schedule, the next priority groups are people over the age of 70, paramedics who transport COVID-19 patients, and some additional healthcare workers        https://web.archive.org/web/20210106190138/https://www.icelandreview.com/ask-ir/whats-the-status-of-covid-19-vaccination-in-iceland/      http://web.archive.org/web/20210103140447/https://www.covid.is/categories/information-on-covid-19-vaccine

Further tightening of restrictions regarding the ongoing lockdown declared early November:    Primary, pre-secondary and secondary education will be provided remotely, except special needs schools and special needs classes in general education schools following the programmes of primary, pre-secondary, individualised primary and pre-secondary education, and secondary education, programmes of development of social skills;    Pre-school, pre-primary education will be provided following the conditions laid down by the Commander of Operations’ decision, in-person pre-school and pre-primary education is recommended only for those children whose parents (adoptive parents or guardians) have no possibilities of working remotely.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020

No change in policy, all school levels remain closed except special needs schools and special needs classes in general education schools (I have decided to remain the level on "3" as all "normal" schools remain closed".    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103153704/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-3-january-2021

Further tightening of restrictions regarding the ongoing lockdown declared early November:    State and municipal institutions and bodies and state and municipal enterprises and the private sector will organise work and provide customer services remotely, except where relevant functions (work) have to be performed at the workplace, while ensuring conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations for the management of the flow of people, safe physical distance, and other key requirements for public health safety, hygiene, and the provision of persons with necessary personal protective equipment    Stores, including those in shopping and/or entertainment centres, marketplaces and other public points of sale will be closed except:    -stores (including those in shopping and/or entertainment centres), whose main business is the retail of food, veterinary, animal feed, pharmacy, optical goods and orthopedic technical devices;  -selling food in marketplaces and public points of sale;  -remote commerce (by internet or other means of communication), where goods are delivered to natural and legal persons or collected at collection points;  -funeral stores;  -outdoor trade in Christmas trees and other festive trees.    Stores that remain open will be required to:    ensure 15 sq. m. of retail space per visitor or serve only one visitor at a time and ensure other conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020

There will be no indoor or outdoor commercial or non-commercial cultural, entertainment, sporting events, celebrations, fairs, festivals or other mass gatherings arranged in public locations of a certain duration at a scheduled time except:    high-performance sporting events without spectators;  funerals attended by maximum 10 persons except family and/or household members and persons providing funeral services.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020

Further tightening of restrictions regarding the ongoing lockdown declared early November:    It is allowed to be in public places in groups of no more than 2 persons or in groups of one family and/or one household.   It is prohibited to hold private parties in public and private venues with the participation of more than one family and/or household and to have close contacts between members of more than one family and/or one household except:    -emergencies, where it is necessary to provide assistance;  -attending to the sick or to those unable to take care of themselves;    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020

It is allowed to be in public places in groups of no more than 2 persons or in groups of one family and/or one household.    It is prohibited:    -to have close contacts between members of more than one family and/or one household except:  emergencies, where it is necessary to provide assistance;  attending to the sick or to those unable to take care of themselves;    -to hold private parties in public and private venues with the participation of more than one family and/or household.     Transport vehicles other than regular public transport (city, long-distance and suburban) or transport vehicles to commute to work may carry groups of no more than 2 persons or groups of members of one family and/or one household. When providing passenger transportation service for a fare by a passenger car on call and by a taxi passenger car, the driver of the vehicle will not be counted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103153704/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-3-january-2021

Further tightening of restrictions regarding the ongoing lockdown declared early November:    Passengers travelling by public transport (city, long-distance and suburban) will be required to travel seated maintaining the distance of at least one meter between each other. No other restrictions, however.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020

No change to previous policy:    Passengers travelling by public transport (city, long-distance and suburban) will be required to travel seated maintaining the distance of at least one meter between each other. No other restrictions, however.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103153704/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-3-january-2021

Further tightening of restrictions regarding the ongoing lockdown declared early November:    It is required to stay at home except:    -to go to work (for work purposes);  -to go shopping;  -to go to/from airports, seaports, bus stations serving international passenger routes;  -to go to your real estate property;  -to go to a funeral;  -for health and other essential services;  -for other essential services or for objectively justified reasons where it is absolutely necessary;  -to go for a walk in open spaces only with members of your family or household;  -to attend to the sick or to those unable to take care of themselves.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228144835/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-23-december-2020

It is required to stay at home except:    to go to work (for work purposes);  to go shopping;  to go to/from airports, seaports, bus stations serving international passenger routes;  to go to your real estate property;  to go to a funeral;  for health and other essential services;  for other essential services or for objectively justified reasons where it is absolutely necessary;  to go for a walk in open spaces only with members of your family or household;  to attend to the sick or to those unable to take care of themselves.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103153704/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-3-january-2021

Travelling between municipalities is restricted.    Except:    -to go to/from airports, seaports, bus stations serving international passenger routes;  -to go to the municipality where you live;  -for the death of close relatives;  -to do work, where the place of employment is in another municipality;  -for health care services;  -for other objectively justified reasons of urgency, where travelling to a municipality other than -the place of residence is absolutely necessary.    -This restriction does not apply to members of one family and/or household travelling to a municipality other than the place of their residence where they have real estate property that is owned by a member of that family and/or household.    https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-3-january-2021

'All passenger flights from the United Kingdom are suspended. The ban will take effect as of 21 December, 04.00, and will last until 31 December, 24.00'    http://web.archive.org/web/20201221151247/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-20-december-2020

Passenger flights from the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland to the Republic of Lithuania are forbidden from 21st December 2020 04:00 up to 31st December 2020 24:00. Exceptionally, flights may only be operated upon receipt a separate permit issued by the Lithuanian Transport Safety Administration in response to the provision of the Minister of Health, Minister of Foreign Affairs  or the Minister for the Interior.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210107143201/https://nvsc.lrv.lt/en/information-on-covid-19/for-arrivals-from-abroad

People returning / arriving from affected countries are subjects to 10-day isolation. Isolation does not apply to those who have a negative test for COVID-19 performed not earlier than 48 hours ago.    You can also be tested in Lithuania. In this case, isolation applies to you until a negative laboratory test is obtained.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210107143201/https://nvsc.lrv.lt/en/information-on-covid-19/for-arrivals-from-abroad
No changes to previous entry of a currently overwhelmed testing infrastructure
No changes to previous entry of a currently overwhelmed testing infrastructure

No changes to previous entry of a currently overwhelmed testing infrastructure    See also:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210107154837/https://www.lrt.lt/en/news-in-english/19/1312892/social-support-bubbles-proposed-to-mitigate-lockdown-stress-in-lithuania

Protective face masks are mandatory in all public places (for all from the age of 6). Exceptions will apply in the following cases:     exercising individuals;  high-performance sports training;  during the provision of a service where a service cannot be provided when a customer is wearing a mask;  persons with disability who cannot wear a mask due to their health condition or where it can adversely affect their health condition. They are recommended to wear a face shield instead.  when outside populated areas (cities, towns, villages, single-homestead settlements and dacha (garden) settlements) and when there are no other people within the radius of 20 metres, except for family members;  children over the age of 6 who are educated under pre-school, pre-primary and primary education programmes will not be required to wear protective equipment covering nose and mouth (face masks, respirators or other equipment) while in education establishments and/or their territories.  Face masks are mandatory in common areas.    It is recommended to wear a face mask at a private party, if held, or when socialising with members of other families /households.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103153704/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-3-january-2021

Lithuania started vaccinations against COVID-19 on 27th of December:    "Lithuania on Saturday started to vaccinate its medical workers against the coronavirus in a coordinated push by the European Union against the global pandemic.  Nijole Ramonaite, a nurse at Vilnius University Hospital Santaros Klinikos, was the first person in the country inoculated by the vaccine produced by Pfizer and BionTech.  Vaccination was launched in hospitals in Vilnius, Kaunas, Klaipeda, Siauliai and Panevezys simultaneously at 8:00 a.m. on Sunday."  https://web.archive.org/web/20201228154724/https://www.baltictimes.com/lithuania_starts_vaccinations_against_covid-19/    Regarding strategy:  Acting Health Minister Aurelijus Veryga said that medics and at-risk people in the country would be vaccinated from the coronavirus first. If a sufficient amount of vaccines is delivered to Lithuania, mass vaccination of the population could start in February or March, according to Veryga.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228154743/https://www.lrt.lt/en/news-in-english/19/1296189/most-people-in-lithuania-to-receive-vaccines-by-mid-summer-says-president

The first doses of the vaccine will be given for the medical staff working in the COVID-19 wards, emergency departments, and those at high risk for COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210107161149/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/lithuanian-healthcare-workers-start-getting-the-covid-19-vaccine

Gatherings in households limited to a maximum of 2 people from the same household who can  be accommodated in a closed or open-air venue.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103223857/https://covid19.public.lu/dam-assets/covid-19/toolbox/nouvelles-mesures/affiche/12-30/10192-DISA-Cov19-Mesures-A4-Part4.pdf

Nationals of an EU country or one of the Schengen Area associated countries are free to enter the European Union, irrespective of the purpose of their stay and not only to return to their home. These people do not need to produce a negative Test before entering the Grand Duchy. Nationals of San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and the Vatican/Holy See are also free to enter the European Union, irrespective of the purpose of their stay and not only to return to their home. These people do not need to produce a negative Test before entering the Grand Duchy either. Third-country nationals may no longer enter the territory of the Grand Duchy until 31 March 2021  (inclusive).     https://web.archive.org/web/20201231203045/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html

It should be noted that from 1 January 2021, these restrictions also apply to third-country nationals residing in the United Kingdom, including UK nationals who do not fall under the provisions of the Withdrawal Agreement (see FAQs).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103224749/https://covid19.public.lu/en/travellers/visiting-luxembourg.html

The first people to be vaccinated are health professionals and staff in hospitals, as well as ambulance drivers, staff in residential care facilities for the elderly and in care and support networks, and people living in these facilities. On Thursday 28 and 29 December, around 800 people from the hospital sector will be vaccinated, and 200 people per hospital establishment for acute treatments respectively. On Wednesday 30 December, staff from senior citizens' homes will be vaccinated - with an additional 400 vaccinations planned. In addition, paramedics transporting COVID-19 patients were offered vaccination during these three days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103233531/https://gouvernement.lu/en/actualites/toutes_actualites/communiques/2020/12-decembre/28-vaccin-covid.html

On 17 December, the government decided to make amendments to Cabinet of Ministers Order No. 655 "Regarding Declaration of the Emergency Situation", strengthening safety measures from 21 December to 11 January.    In education:    Winter holidays will be extended for 1 week until 8 January for pupils from grade 1 to grade 6.  There will be no practical classes in person (also not individually). Also in professional and higher education, various courses, etc. classes may only take place remotely. The exception is clinical training in residency.  Interest-related education and various practices can take place only remotely.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111213254/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/within-three-week-period-movement-people-must-be-significantly-reduced-allowing-us-gift
No change to previous policy (running until 11th January)

On 17 December, the The Cabinet of Ministers decided to make amendments to Cabinet of Ministers Order No. 655 "Regarding Declaration of the Emergency Situation", strengthening safety measures from 19 December to 11 January.    From 19 December to 11 January, the rules that were until now applied to holidays and public holidays will apply on a daily basis, but the product groups that may be sold during this period will be expanded. This means that during these 3 weeks only the following shall operate: pharmacies (including veterinary pharmacies), optical goods stores, fuel stations,  points of sale where essential goods are sold (groceries, PPE, hygiene products etc.).  At the same time, the requirements for points of sale have been reinforced: at least 15 m2 of the available space will have to be provided for one visitor (excluding the area occupied by shelves, equipment, etc.), the number of visitors cannot exceed the number of available trolleys/carts, and visitors must attend the store alone (it is allowed to bring children under the age of 12 or an assistant if necessary).  On-site services, which can be dispensed with for three weeks, are prohibited, including beauty care, piercing, tattooing, photoshoots, entertainment, and wellness (SPA, saunas, games rooms, etc.).  Libraries, exhibition sites and other cultural venues will not work, and it will also not be allowed to organize fairs (including Christmas markets). Indoor premises of museums will be closed for visitors, but the open-air areas of museums will continue to operate,  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111213254/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/within-three-week-period-movement-people-must-be-significantly-reduced-allowing-us-gift  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111214926/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/during-holiday-season-period-silence-must-be-observed-reducing-contact-and-refraining
No change to previous policy (running until 11th January)
No change to previous policy (running until 11th January)
No change to previous policy (running until 11th January)
No change to previous policy (running until 11th January)

No closure measures. That being said:  From 7 December, in order to protect people in public transport, the number of passengers must not exceed 50% of the vehicle's capacity. If it is not possible to control the embarkation and disembarkation of passengers, the vehicle must be provided with instructions on the use of seats to ensure physical distancing. In public transport, face masks must be worn by both the driver and passengers, including children from the age of 7.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201207030317/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/emergency-situation-has-been-extended-until-11-january-introducing-stricter-safety

On Tuesday, 29 December, The Cabinet of Ministers agreed on a “holiday curfew”, stipulating that all residents of Latvia from 30 December to 4 January, as well as on 8 and 9 January from 22.00 to 5.00, must stay at their place of residence. There are currently no plans to restrict daytime movement. Consequently, sales and service outlets will be open from 6.00 to 21.00, so that employees can get from home to work and back without breaking the rules.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111220036/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/government-conceptually-agrees-new-years-eve-curfew

No specific measures implemented. There are currently no plans to restrict daytime movement. The clarifications in the security measures for the holiday season approved by the Cabinet of Ministers do not restrict freedom of movement. Public transport will continue to run and people are encouraged to take the opportunity to spend time outdoors in nature.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210111214926/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/during-holiday-season-period-silence-must-be-observed-reducing-contact-and-refraining  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111220036/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/government-conceptually-agrees-new-years-eve-curfew

In coordination with other EU Member States aiming to protect the public from the spread of the new coronavirus type in Latvia, the Cabinet of Ministers decided to suspend passenger traffic through airports, ports, as well as by bus from and to the United Kingdom from 21 December to 1 January 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111222314/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/passenger-services-and-united-kingdom-will-be-suspended-december-21

It is allowed to enter Latvia, provided that the guidelines developed by the Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (SPKC) are being followed. When arriving from countries with a 14-day cumulative number of COVID-19 cases that is higher than 50 per 100,000 inhabitants, self-isolation must be observed for 10 days.  10-day self-isolation must be observed when entering Latvia from the countries listed in the “National COVID-19 morbidity rates” section of the SPKC website.  If a person is arriving from a “safe” country by transiting through an “unsafe country”, the person must observe self-isolation; in order to avoid self-isolation, a different return route must be chosen.  Self-isolation means staying in the place of self-isolation without exposing other persons to the risk of infection and without making direct contact with others (not receiving guests, not visiting anyone, not going to work or public places where many people may be present, except for going to the shop or getting to the place of residence or of self-isolation immediately after arriving in Latvia, using a mouth and nose covering).  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207042737/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/covid-19-frequently-asked-questions-and-answers

Downtime allowance and allowance for employee salary subsidies will be available to entrepreneurs in all sectors. The support will be available for the period from 9 November 2020 to 31 December 2020. The Cabinet of Ministers on Nov 24th, has decided that the above-mentioned types of aid will be available to taxpayers affected by the Covid-19 restrictive measures in all sectors.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207043641/https://www.mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/vitenbergs-downtime-allowance-and-allowance-employee-salary-subsidies-will-be-available

http://web.archive.org/web/20210106203752/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/economics/support-entrepreneurs-and-employees    Income support is ongoing. You can apply for the allowance for November until 15 December, for December - until 15 January, and for January - until 15 February.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210106203752/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/economics/support-entrepreneurs-and-employees

No change to previous measures. Broad economic relief and support available.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210106203752/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/economics/support-entrepreneurs-and-employees
Coordinated public campaign still ongoing. Specific websites in place as well as information on social media among others:  http://web.archive.org/web/20201207044619/https://covid19.gov.lv/en

No change to previous entry. - You can take a free Covid-19 test if you have a doctor's referral. If you suspect you have Covid-19, you should first contact your family doctor. If the healthcare professional, after hearing the patient’s symptoms, decides that a test is needed, an e-referral will be issued.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207042737/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/covid-19-frequently-asked-questions-and-answers

From 19 December to 25 January, residents may get tested for Covid-19 without a doctor's referral if they have symptoms of the disease (signs of an acute respiratory infection, fever, olfactory disturbances, loss of taste, etc.).   http://web.archive.org/web/20210111225847/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/covid-19/about-covid-19/who-can-be-tested-covid-19-free

No evident policy change.  There is a voluntary contact tracing app available, however its not mandatory to use.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201026225622/https://www.baltictimes.com/around_40_000_people_have_downloaded_latvia_s_covid-19_contact_tracing_app/

Mandatory face masks in public places indoors if more than two people are present, and on public transport.  - A face mask must be used by everyone from the age of 7 in premises outside the household if there is more than one person in the room  - Face masks must be used by everyone in public transport, incl. children from 7 years of age  - A homemade mask should be made of at least three layers of suitable material (cotton, nylon, etc.) and have ties to secure it behind the ears or behind the head  - Face mask must be used by everyone in educational institutions both during studies and outside the classroom (for children from 7 years of age from 4 January)  - The organiser of the event or the service provider must not allow those into the premises who do not fulfil the obligation to use a face mask or do it incorrectly (the face mask must cover the mouth and nose).  - Wearing a face mask is not obligatory for children under 7 years of age or for people who have difficulty wearing a mask, for example, due to functional disorders  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111232931/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

The first vaccination rooms in Latvia started operating on December 28, 2020. The European Medicines Agency (EMA) and the European Commission (EC) have approved the quality, safety and efficacy of the first two Covid-19 vaccines. These are the vaccine Comirnaty manufactured by Pfizer-BioNTech and the vaccine manufactured by Moderna.      The vaccine will first be given to medical staff working with Covid-19 patients and to the staff of the Emergency Medical Service (EMS). After that, other vaccines will be gradually delivered to Latvia. The first vaccines will be given to healthcare workers working with Covid-19 patients in hospitals and to the Emergency Medical Service. Afterwards, vaccines will be provided to the following groups in this order: ther health care workers;  Employees and clients of social care centres;  People with chronic diseases;  People over the age of 60;  People working in operational services;  Employees of medical institutions;  People in places of imprisonment;  All other residents of Latvia. It is planned that all other residents of Latvia will be able to be vaccinated starting from the second quarter of 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210111233236/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/vaccine  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111233533/https://www.spkc.gov.lv/lv/kad-vakcinas-bus-pieejamas-latvija

Further tightening of measures, effective on 11th of January 2020.     Restaurants will be open only for lunch. Access to restaurants will be limited solely to residents of Monaco and those who work in the country Distance of at least 1.5 metres between restaurant tables (instead of 1 metre).  Bars are closed (the State is funding strengthened provisions for total temporary layoff at a rate of 100%), except for hotel bars which can remain open until 10 pm for hotel residents.    Takeaway sales will be forbidden after 7 pm. Deliveries are permitted until 9 pm.      Otherwise, current measures continue to apply.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150310/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

Further tightening of measures, effective on 11th of January 2020. Curfew increased from 7 pm to 6 am. Otherwise, current measures continue to apply.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150310/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

As bars are closed with the further tightening of lockdown measures, the State is funding strengthened provisions for total temporary layoff at a rate of 100%, except for hotel bars which can remain open until 10 pm for hotel residents    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150310/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

Further tightening of measures, effective on 11th of January 2020. Masks must be worn in all public spaces, and in all closed spaces open to the public and shared areas of private spaces    Children aged under five years and people who are exercising outdoors do not need to wear a mask. Those exercising should carry a mask in their pocket in case they need to put it on, however.  The wearing of masks in private spaces is strongly recommended, particularly when someone from outside the household or a vulnerable person is present.    Otherwise, current measures continue to apply.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150310/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

"Initially, vaccinations will be available to senior residents aged 75 or over, living either in care homes or in the community, who have received a letter from the Government inviting them to contact the COVID-19 Call Centre"    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115170152/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-2019/Actualites/First-COVID-19-vaccination-in-Principality    In general:    Vaccines will become available gradually, and so the Prince’s Government has had to establish priorities to ensure that at-risk groups are at the front of the queue. These groups are:    -Elderly people living in care settings    -People aged over 75    -People aged 65–74    -People with underlying health conditions (obesity (BMI>30), particularly among younger people, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and respiratory disease, complex high blood pressure disorders, heart disease, type 1 or type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease, recent history of cancer (within the last three years), solid organ transplant or haematopoietic stem cell transplant, Down’s syndrome, etc.)    -Healthcare workers, etcA    The vaccination campaign will therefore be rolled out in several phases to target each category of the population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115165719/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/tout-sur-les-vaccins/vaccination-procedure/
No change.
No policy change

Current restrictions from 30 November remain in place until 15 January. While there is some information to suggest schools were closed by the government on 21 December, other reports indicate that schools are generally operating in person with health guidelines in place and that beginning 11 January after the winter holidays, school will resume in-person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210110002114/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/01/06/21000070  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110001613/https://mecc.gov.md/ro/content/ministerul-educatiei-culturii-si-cercetarii-prezinta-datele-privind-evolutia-situatiei-6  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110000414/https://gov.md/en/comunicate-presa  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109235654/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

"Authorities in Moldova are maintaining international entry restrictions as of Dec. 7 to combat the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19). Authorities designate all countries with COVID-19 infection rates of over 100 per 100,000 population as "red" or high-risk locations. Most travelers from red locations are prohibited from entering Moldova, excluding Moldovan citizens and residents and their immediate family members, individuals with a work or study permit for Moldova, individuals in transit, and individuals traveling for urgent reasons. All permitted arrivals from red countries must self-isolate for 14 days upon arrival. As of Dec. 7, 63 countries are designated as red locations, including Canada, France, Germany, Romania, Russia, Spain, Ukraine, the UK, and the US; the full list can be found on the Ministry of Health website."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103132254/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/410051/moldova-covid-19-related-state-of-emergency-in-effect-as-of-dec-7-update-10

15 December  The Netherlands entered its strictest lockdown yet from 15 December until at least Tuesday 19 January.     Primary and secondary schools, schools for secondary vocation education (MBO) and higher education institutions (universities and HBO) will deliver teaching online in order to reduce in-person contact. They may make exceptions for those sitting exams and interim exams this academic year, as well as for practical training and to support vulnerable pupils and students.    In order to allow enough time to make preparations, the measures for schools, educational institutions and childcare centres will apply from Wednesday 16 December. They will be in place until Sunday 17 January.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210106111540/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

Until January 17th, primary and secondary schools, schools for secondary vocation education (MBO) and higher education institutions (universities and HBO) will deliver teaching online in order to reduce in-person contact. Childcare centres will also be closed. Primary schools and childcare centres will remain open for children whose parents work in critical sectors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

15 December  The Netherlands entered its strictest lockdown yet from 15 December until at least Tuesday 19 January.     Non essential businesses closed- Only people in medical and paramedical contact-based professions can continue to carry out their work.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210106111540/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people  r

People should therefore continue to work from home, unless it is absolutely necessary that they go into work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

Venues such as museums, theatres, amusement parks, zoos, casinos, saunas, indoor sporting venues, and establishments serving food and drink (including in hotels) will be closed throughout this period.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

From Tuesday 15 December to 19 January inclusive:    Only go outdoors alone, with members of your household or in a group of no more than 2 people.  You should receive no more than 2 visitors aged 13 or over to your home per day.        https://web.archive.org/web/20210106111540/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

The government is also advising people to receive no more than 2 people aged 13 or over at home per day. There is an exception to this on 24, 25 and 26 December: then, up to 3 people can visit, excluding children under 13. Outside, the maximum group size is 2 people, including during the festive period.        https://web.archive.org/web/20210106111540/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

The government is also advising people to receive no more than 2 people aged 13 or over at home per day. Outside, the maximum group size is 2 people, including during the festive period.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

The Netherlands entered its strictest lockdown yet from 15 December until at least Tuesday 19 January.       Public transport is for essential travel only.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210106111540/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

Public transport is for essential travel only.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

Stay at home as much as possible, including during the festive season. We know that this is an effective way of reducing infection rates. Coming into contact with fewer people reduces the risk of infection and makes it harder for coronavirus to spread.    People should therefore continue to work from home, unless it is absolutely necessary that they go into work. The government is also advising people to receive no more than 2 people aged 13 or over at home per day.     As people are allowed to enter each other's houses, cannot code this as a 2- require stay home, more a strong recommendation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210106111540/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

From the government's page: "Stay at home as much as possible, including during the festive season."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

The Netherlands entered its strictest lockdown yet from 15 December until at least Tuesday 19 January.     Cannot see explicit ban on domestic movement but strong recommendation to stay at home      https://web.archive.org/web/20210106111540/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

Stay at home recommended, no traveling.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

Do not book any foreign travel until mid-March at the earliest and do not travel abroad.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

Extensive support packages in place for workers    https://web.archive.org/web/20210106121236/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/onderwerpen/coronavirus-financiele-regelingen/overzicht-financiele-regelingen

Two of the temporary measures are the Temporary emergency scheme for job retention (NOW) and the Temporary self-employment income support and loan scheme (TOZO).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201123175030/https://business.gov.nl/corona/overview/the-coronavirus-and-your-company/

Tozo3 and 4: Self-employed professionals can apply for Tozo, the temporary benefit to bridge the loss of income over the months October 2020 - July 2021 in the municipality where they live.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201123175030/https://business.gov.nl/corona/overview/the-coronavirus-and-your-company/

Through government websites, social media, media/news outlets, etc. Downloadable pamphlets available.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112024324/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-test

If you have (mild) symptoms of COVID-19, make an appointment to get tested. People who do not have symptoms can only get tested if one or both of the following apply: Contact tracing has shown they have been in close contact with an infected person. They have received a notification from the CoronaMelder app following contact with someone who has tested positive for coronavirus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112024324/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-test

CoronaMelder app put in place for tracing and contacting potentially infected peoples.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112024324/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-test

Everyone aged 13 or over is required to wear a face mask for general use in the following situations: In buildings and covered spaces that are accessible to the public (in so far as these are open). Both customers and staff should wear a face mask in locations where contact-based professions are carried out. On public transport, in stations, on platforms and at bus and tram stops.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112025205/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/tackling-new-coronavirus-in-the-netherlands/basic-rules-for-everyone

In order to maintain control of the spread of infection and to limit new increases in infection rates, strengthened national infection prevention measures are being implemented on a temporary basis for two weeks effective 4 January.  Schools and education  All teaching and planned events at universities, university colleges and vocational training schools will take place digitally until 18 January. (New)  All upper and lower secondary schools in Norway will switch to a red level of alert. In order to maintain control of the spread of infection and to limit new increases in infection rates, strengthened national infection prevention measures are being implemented on a temporary basis for two weeks effective 4 January.  Private gatherings and events  A maximum of five people may gather for private gatherings, such as a birthday in hired premises, outside their own some home. If there are more than five members of one household, then all members of the household are permitted to meet. (New)  There is a limit of ten people for indoor sporting events, cultural events, seminars, faith community gatherings, ceremonies, etc., in addition to a limit of 200 people where everyone in the audience is seated in fixed seating. Up to 50 people are permitted to attend funerals, even if the seating is not fixed. (New)  Regardless, the majority of these events will not comply with the current national guidelines and should therefore be postponed or cancelled.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210106093622/https:/www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/introduction-of-further-national-infection-prevention-measures/id2826466/

The Norwegian Institute of Public Health (NIPH/FHI) recommends that anyone who suspects they might be infected by the coronavirus is given the opportunity to be tested. Those that should get tested are:    Anyone showing symptoms of COVID-19, including anyone experiencing a sudden onset of symptoms of a respiratory tract infection.  Anyone who is a close contact to someone with confirmed COVID-19*.  Anyone arriving in Norway after having visited a red contry/area during the preceding 10-day period.  Anyone who suspects they might be infected by the coronavirus.  Other persons as assessed by a doctor.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201113155943/https://www.helsenorge.no/en/coronavirus/testing-symptoms-and-close-contacts/

Poland faces a real threat of a third wave of the coronavirus pandemic, Health Minister Adam Niedzielski said on Monday, adding he would recommend that current restrictions continue until at least Jan. 17.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201217123926/https://news.yahoo.com/poland-faces-real-threat-pandemic-121958079.html

From the 28th of December:  Only essential stores will remain open.   Hotels will only be available to uniformed services, medics, patients of specialised hospitals, COS centers and staff hotels.   The ski slopes will close and sports infrastructure is only available to professional athletes.  The following pre-existing restrictions are extended:  Gyms, fitness clubs and aquaparks are closed.   Restaurants are closed, meals are only available for takeaway or delivery.   Hairdressing and beauty salons operate under sanitary conditions.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210101210448/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przedluzamy-etap-odpowiedzialnosci-i-wprowadzamy-dodatkowe-ograniczenia

State of Emergency in force until 15 January.   -	The use of face masks is mandatory.  -	Public transports are limited to 2/3 of the capacity.  -	In taxis / TVDE, the front seats must be used only by the driver, and passenger occupancy cannot exceed 2/3 of the remaining space.  -	Rent-a-Car - In vehicles with a capacity of 5 seats or less, they can be fully occupied if they belong to the same household. If the vehicle has a capacity for more than 5 seats, its capacity is limited to 2/3 of the total, unless they are part of the same household.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210112033409/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

A,C:      Portugal begins vaccinating frontline health workers on 27 December. News reports and government immunisation dashboard shows that frontline workers and elderly are the two eligible groups currently.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111135939/https://www.publico.pt/2020/12/23/sociedade/noticia/portugal-recebe-70200-doses-vacina-covid-28-dezembro-1944109    https://archive.vn/m1Bk9

Vaccination task force coordinator Francisco Ramos has set out Portugal’s ‘programme’. If all goes according to plan (meaning the Pfizer vaccination gets European Medicine Agency approval later this month), Phase One will start in January immunising:    People over the age of 50 with at least one of the following pathologies: cardiac insufficiency, heart disease, renal insufficiency or chronic respiratory disease requiring ventilation.  Residents of old people’s homes and those interned in professional continuous care facilities  Healthcare professionals directly involved in caring for the sick, Armed Forces personnel, security forces and all ‘essential service personnel’ (criteria still to be defined).    Code remains the same as this extra clause for clinically vulnerable has not yet been bought into effect    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111141448/https://www.portugalresident.com/portugals-vaccination-programme-opens-with-950000-getting-shots-between-january-and-february/

According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces. Also, to avoid the congestion of public transport, it is proposed to all public institutions and all economic operators to organize work schedule (where telework is not possible) into at least two groups to start/finish the activity at a difference of at least two hours.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201120195835/https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA2dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjAl/MkYxMSUyRjA2JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf

The Ministry of Health published the recommendations for preventing the spread of coronavirus (working from home where it is possible, people should avoid crowded areas and limit to the maximum any direct contact with other people, other than those who are part of the same family). Also, according to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 (extended through Decision 58/10.12.20) of The National Emergency Committee, in all localities in Romania, it is in place a ban for traffic persons outside the home between 23:00 and 5:00 (exception for travel in professional interest, for medical assistance). The Ministry of Interior published the list of quarantined localities.  Link: https://archive.fo/cUlEp,  https://archive.fo/T7Aib, https://web.archive.org/web/20201212161456/https://www.gov.ro/fisiere/pagini_fisiere/Hotarare_CNSU_nr._58_din_10.12.2020.pdf and https://archive.fo/un88p

On 20th of November, The National Committee for Emergency Situations published Decision no.55 regarding the approval of the list of countries/areas of epidemiological risk for which the quarantine measure is instituted on persons arriving in Romania from them. Also, there are screening procedures implemented at the “Henri Coanda” International Airport (three thermal scanners and a joint action plan with the Border Police and the Public Health Directorate to collect questionnaires from travelers arriving in the country and to distribute information about local measures and restrictions).  According to the Decision 56/4.12.2020 of The National Committee for Emergency Situations, the list of countries of high epidemiological risk for which the quarantine measure is instituted on the persons arriving in Romania from them was approved.  Link: https://archive.fo/pUara and https://archive.fo/s1GX6
