The measures introduced by GEO 30/2020 include:   1.	The criteria for sending employees into technical unemployment and minimum income ensured for freelancers working in industries where activity is reduced or interrupted due to the pandemic.  2.	The conditions for granting free paid days to parents, to supervise their children during the temporary closure of educational establishments.  3.	The online submission of the documentation needed to gain access to social benefits.  4.	The measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons.    Link: https://archive.fo/FtT0q

On 22nd of October, the government approved the application of the simplified alternative procedure for granting payment rescheduling for a maximum of 12 months. Beneficiaries of the simplified staggering facility are all taxpayers.  According to Emergency Ordinance 69/14.05.2020, the authorities have adopted fiscal measures to help taxpayers overcome the problems caused by the COVID-19 pandemic (granting bonuses, extension of the deadline for submitting the Single Declaration, tax facilities for incentives and bonuses granted by the employer from the salary fund for the period of emergency to employees whose activity involves risk of infection with SARS-CoV-2, bonuses regarding the annual building tax and the monthly building tax, cancellation of ancillary payment obligations.  Link: https://archive.fo/OJIQT and https://archive.fo/hVM21

Ministry of Health published “Recommendations on responsible social behavior in preventing the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19)” and “Recommended measures to reduce the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic”. On 29th of October, The Government of Romania announced the List of infection diseases for which the isolation of persons is established at their home. The same document establishes the basic health units in which sick people can be treated with diseases provided in the list of infectious diseases. Also, “Datelazi.ro” (Updated data) project was released pro-bon by Code for Romania in partnership with the Government of Romania through the Authority for the Digitalization of Romania, containing data and information provided by the Government of Romania.   Links: https://archive.fo/cUlEp, https://archive.fo/klswT , https://archive.fo/Vi0vG and https://archive.fo/X428Q

An official document regarding contact tracing and testing of contacts of COVID-19 confirmed patient was released by National Center for Surveillance and Control of Transmissible Diseases on 23rd of July 2020. On 28th of October, the Ministry of Health published updated the flow of information used in reporting SARS CoV-2 virus infection data.  According to this document, the Directorates of Public Health (DSP) have the obligation to identify and confirm, following the epidemiological investigation, direct contacts of each person tested positive.   Link: https://archive.fo/thRdi and https://archive.fo/FUhtr

According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 (extended through Decision 58/10.12.2020) of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces, regardless the value of the cumulative incidence rate of cases in the last 14 days (as it previously of this decision was). The Government approved the Vaccination Strategy against SARA-CoV-2 in Romania. The document establishes the vision, principles, and mode of action for the administration in Romania of COVID-19 vaccines authorized by the European Medicines Agency. Also, the chairman of the National Coordinating Committee for Vaccination Activities against COVID-19 announced that the National Vaccine Storage Center is ready to receive vaccines after the European Medicines Agency issues the conditional marketing authorization. There are three stages of vaccination: first for health care workers, second -for the population at risk, for essential staff and the last stage – for the general population.  Link: https://archive.fo/KYZQL and https://archive.fo/KYZQL

The Government approved the Vaccination Strategy against SARA-CoV-2 in Romania. The document establishes the vision, principles, and mode of action for the administration in Romania of COVID-19 vaccines authorized by the European Medicines Agency. There are three stages of vaccination: first for health care workers, second -for the population at risk, for essential staff and the last stage – for the general population. On 27th of December, the first stage started with the first 10 000 doses of vaccines in all 10 infectious disease hospitals on the front lines in the fight against COVID-19. The winter break in Moscow schools has been extended until 17 January 2021; this is valid for colleges, extracurricular activities for children, and sport schools supervised by the City Government. Extension was recommended to private educational institutions. Sixth to 11th grades are to study remotely until the end of the second quarter of the 2020-21 school year.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104082129/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/

Free travel for Moscow residents aged 65+ who must stay at home is suspended. People with chronic diseases and pregnant women must also stay home. Has been extended to the 15th of January.  People in risk groups are kindly requested to refrain from seeing their relatives who live in separate households and to ask younger family members to do the shopping. On 18 December, Minister of Health Zoran Loncar stated today in Novi Sad that the first doses of Pfizer vaccine will arrive in Serbia on Monday or Tuesday, adding that slightly less than 5,000 doses will arrive in the first tranche and that they will be received by users of nursing homes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219183423/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/165232/first-doses-of-pfizer-vaccine-in-serbia-on-monday.php

On 30 December 2020, Minister of Health Zlatibor Loncar stated in Novi Sad that the vaccination of health workers began today and that those working in infectious diseases clinics and emergency centres have already been vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102195559/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/165717/vaccination-of-health-workers-begins.php

State Secretary of the Ministry of Health Mirsad Djerlek announced: "We plan to vaccinate about 11,000 people by the end of the week, with half of the vaccines being allocated to health workers and half to gerontology centers and social welfare institutions".    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111210924/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/165825/vaccination-of-11000-people-planned-until-end-of-week.php

The Prime Minister Ana Brnabic stated that that there will be enough vaccines available for all citizens who want to be vaccinated against coronavirus (agreements exist for 8 million doses for 4 million of inhabitants). The plan for mass immunisation will be adopted by the crisis response team during the week of 18-24 January 2021.  Brnabic expressed the expectation that the first vaccination point will be opened at the Belgrade Fair by the end of the week of 18-24 January, adding that from 11 January, citizens will be able to apply to the system through which they will be able to express their desire to be vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111212830/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166035/preconditions-for-beginning-of-mass-vaccination-provided.php

No policy change.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111194136/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166089/all-epidemiological-measures-remain-in-force.ph  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111204053/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/

On 26 December, the first person received a vaccine and roll-out out 4 additional hospitals was scheduled to begin 27 December. Four waves of vaccination are planned:  1. healthcare staff, employees of nursing homes, critical infrastructure;  2. people older than 65 years, people suffering from chronic diseases, clients of nursing homes;  3. marginalised groups, homeless people, asylum seekers, teachers;  4. everybody older than 18 years (voluntary principle).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102214442/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22562138/vaccines-have-arrived.html

High schools are closed from 7 December until 6 January. On 3 December, the Public Health Agency issued a 'recommendation' to close all high schools (gymnasieskolor - ages 16-19) for a month and move all classes online. This does not include exams which cannot be taken at a distance.     In line with the Interpretation Guide on C1, I have coded this as '2', since "if the situation is that all schools are closed ... then that would count as a full closure".    http://web.archive.org/web/20201207153005/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/contentassets/27a3b8becacc47edbfa51273b4931886/beslut-2020-12-03-rekommendation-om-delvis-stangning-och-overgang-till-fjarr-eller-distansundervisning-gymnasieskolan.pdf    http://web.archive.org/web/20201207154159/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/regler-for-forskolor-och-skolor-som-ar-oppna-stangda-eller-varit-stangda-under-coronapandemin

The measures have been extended until 24 January: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221201801/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/regler-for-forskolor-och-skolor-som-ar-oppna-stangda-eller-varit-stangda-under-coronapandemin

The Public Health Agency has 'recommended' to close all upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor - ages 16-19) and move all classes online for the period of 7 December 2020 to 24 January 2021. This does not include exams which cannot be taken at a distance.     In line with the Interpretation Guide on C1, I have coded this as '2', since "if the situation is that all schools are closed ... then that would count as a full closure".    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104153119/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/regler-for-forskolor-och-skolor-som-ar-oppna-stangda-eller-varit-stangda-under-coronapandemin

The Swedish Public Health Agency recommends that the principals of the country's upper secondary schools continue to keep their schools partially closed and conduct distance or distance education until 24 January 2021. … The minor adjustments to the recommendation from 7 January mean that the principals will be given the opportunity for additional flexibility with regard to students in the introductory programs, which will enable in-person teaching where necessary, for instance for vulnerable students.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210108131831/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/januari/gymnasieskolan-fortsatter-med-distansundervisning/

From 11 January, in addition to schools for ages 16-19 (gymnasieskolor), schools for ages 13-15 (högstadieskolor) are also able to switch to distance learning to avoid congestion on the school premises and in public transport.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112093953/https://www.regeringen.se/informationsmaterial/2021/01/en-planerad-andring-i-forordning-2020115/

The Public Health Agency recommends principals of gymnasieskolor (ages 16-19) to switch to distance learning until 24 January. Principals of högstadieskolor (ages 13-15) are also allowed to switch to distance learning to reduce crowding in schools and on public transport.      http://web.archive.org/web/20210115153731/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen
No change in policy

The ban on public gatherings of over 8 people remains in effect. This does not apply to most workplaces, but does affect some sectors to the point where they are required to close, such as amusement parks, dance and circus performances, markets and fairs.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104153454/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

The ban on public gatherings of over 8 people remains in effect. This does not apply to most workplaces, but does affect some sectors to the point where they are required to close, such as amusement parks, dance and circus performances, markets and fairs.    Furthermore, all public buildings are shut down until 24 January. This applies, for example, to bathhouses, sports halls and museums.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210108133122/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

In addition to the measures mentioned in the previous note, on 10 January, a new covid-19 law came into force which enabled the government to restrict numbers in shops and businesses, and close public places such as shopping centres and gyms. It has not yet mandated such closures, but from 10 January, shops, shopping centers, gyms and bathhouses must calculate the number of visitors to allow for 10 sqm per visitor. In addition, the maximum limit of 8 participants will also apply to private events in party centres and club houses.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112112903/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/januari/butiker-gym-och-kopcentrum-maste-begransa-antalet-besokare/

Some workplaces, including amusement parks, dance and circus performances, markets and fairs, have to close because of the ban on public gatherings of over 8 people. Under the new covid-19 law, which came into force on 10 January, shops, shopping centers, gyms and bathhouses must calculate the number of visitors to allow for 10 sqm per visitor. Furthermore, the ban on serving alcohol between 8 pm and 11 am has been extended to 24 January.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210115160338/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    http://web.archive.org/web/20210115154227/https://www.krisinformation.se/nyheter/20212/januari/regeringen-alkoholforbudet-fran-klockan-20-forlangs

In force from 14 December, the Public Health Agency replaced its regional advice with national regulations and general advice, in light of the upcoming Christmas holidays. This includes the recommendation to limit the number of encounters and spend time in a "small circle" and avoid being part of several different groups, in order to reduce the number of close contacts as much as possible. "The fewer, the better." A smaller circle ["mindre krets"] is "a few people, but it is not possible to say an exact number. Who and how many are included in the circle can vary based on each individual's life situation. For some it may be some close friends, for others the immediate family."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214164556/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/jul-och-andra-hogtider/

The ban on public gatherings of over 8 people remains in effect. The Public Health Agency has "strongly recommended" to also adhere to these requirements in private.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104153454/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    In the words of home minister Mikael Damberg: "The recommendations from the agencies aren't some kind of tips for the public -- they should be followed."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214162622/https://www.thelocal.se/20201211/sweden-to-send-mass-text-banging-home-christmas-covid-rules

No change, max 8 people in public and strict recommendation to also follow this in private: https://web.archive.org/web/20210108133122/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

Whereas the 8-people limit was initially only for public gatherings, under the newly enacted covid-19 law, it also applies to private events in party centres and club houses.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112112903/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/januari/butiker-gym-och-kopcentrum-maste-begransa-antalet-besokare/

No change: http://web.archive.org/web/20210115160338/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

In force from 14 December, the Public Health Agency replaced its regional advice with national regulations and general advice, in light of the upcoming Christmas holidays. These are divided into rules and advice aimed at individuals, with an emphasis on personal responsibility, and rules and advice aimed at businesses. Re public transport, for individuals, the recommendation is to limit the use of public transport as much as possible. Public transport companies should: 1) run schedules in such a way as to reduce the risk of congestion; 2) limit the number of passengers per vehicle; 3) inform their passengers on how they can reduce the risk of spreading the virus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214164556/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/jul-och-andra-hogtider/

No change since last entry. The Public Health Agency recommends to limit the use of public transport as much as possible. "You should avoid traveling by public transport and other public transport where a seat reservation is not offered. In the first place, you should use other modes of transport, such as walking, cycling or driving your own car."  Its recommendations to public transport companies include: 1) run schedules in such a way as to reduce the risk of congestion; 2) limit the number of passengers per vehicle; 3) inform their passengers on how they can reduce the risk of spreading the virus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104154139/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/om-du-planerar-att-resa/i-kollektivtrafiken/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104154249/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/jul-och-andra-hogtider/

In addition to the general temporary entry ban for non-EU non-essential travellers, as of 22 December, an additional entry ban was introduced for travellers from the UK and Denmark. The entry ban from the UK is due to the spread and mutation of COVID-19 that have been reported there. The entry ban from Denmark is mainly to reduce the risk of congestion and the spread of the virus in shopping centres and restaurants in Skåne County.    Exempt from the entry ban are Swedish citizens, people transporting goods, and people living in Denmark and working across the border in Sweden.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201218171409/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/12/temporary-entry-ban-extended-until-31-march-2021-and-amended-due-to-brexit/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201230204915/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/12/ban-on-entry-into-sweden-from-the-united-kingdom-and-denmark/

The general temporary entry ban for non-EU non-essential travellers as well as travellers from the UK and Denmark remains in place.     As of 1 January 2021, people exempt from the ban and travelling from the UK are required to present a negative test result at the most 72 hours before arriving in Sweden.     This requirement does not apply to those transporting goods – who may therefore enter the country without presenting a negative test result. This is to avoid impeding the transport of essential goods, such as pharmaceuticals or medical equipment.    Nor does the requirement apply to Swedish citizens, who always have the right to enter Sweden. However, the recommendation of the Public Health Agency of Sweden still applies, i.e. that everyone who has been in the UK should get tested for COVID-19 immediately upon arrival to Sweden, remain at home and get tested again after five days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104160031/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/12/negative-covid-19-test-result-required-for-entry-into-sweden-from-uk/

There is currently no regulation that requires the use of facemasks, but the Public Health Agency has announced that it will produce a national guideline on the use of facemasks in public transport on weekdays before 7 January 2021, when most people return to work or school after the holidays.     The public transport providers will need to inform travelers about the recommendation to use facemasks and should provide facemasks free of charge for those travellers who do not bring their own.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201221201620/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2020/december/ytterligare-atgarder-for-att-bromsa-smitta-och-skydda-halsa/

Currently no policy, but from 7 January, the Public Health Agency recommends the use of face masks during rush hour (7-9 am + 4-6 pm) in public transport. The recommendation applies to everyone born in 2004 and earlier. Individuals who for medical reasons cannot wear mouth guards are excluded from the recommendation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104161220/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/om-sjukdomen-och-smittspridning/smittspridning/munskydd/

From 7 January, there is a new general recommendation for people born before 2004 (16 and above) to wear face masks on public transport between 7-9 am and 4-6 pm on weekdays, if it is not possible to ensure good social distance by booking a separate seat.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210108131814/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2020/december/munskydd-i-kollektivtrafiken-fran-den-7-januari/

Only recommended on public transport between 7-9 am and 4-6 pm on weekdays for people born before 2004 (16 and above).     http://web.archive.org/web/20210115160118/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/om-sjukdomen-och-smittspridning/smittspridning/munskydd/
No change in policy since last entry: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221200714/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/vaccination-mot-covid-19/

The first vaccinations took place on 27 December. The Public Health Agency has recommended different phases for the vaccination, according to the need for protection of respective groups. During Phase 1, which started on 27 December, elderly living in care homes or receive home care under the Social Services Act, staff working directly with these people, and adults living with someone belonging to this risk group are eligible. Phase 2 is expected to start in February 2021.     Note: I have coded this as 1, because eligibility is specifically related to the elderly. Some key workers can be vaccinated, but exclusively those working with the elderly, so I considered this not enough to code it as 2 groups (elderly + key workers).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210104161641/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2020/december/vaccinationerna-i-sverige-har-inletts/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104162056/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/vaccination-mot-covid-19/rekommendationer-for-vaccination-mot-covid-19/

On 5 January, the Public Health Agency announced that the vaccination for certain frontline workers, for instance people working at the ICU, "may need to be brought forward" in some regions. I cannot confirm whether vaccinations of frontline workers outside of the elderly care are already taking place, so for now, I have decided to leave the coding the same.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112113316/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/januari/vaccinering-for-viss-vardpersonal-kan-tidigarelaggas/

No change since last entry: https://web.archive.org/web/20210108140238/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/vaccination-mot-covid-19/fragor-och-svar-om-vaccination-mot-covid-19/     Note: I have coded this as 1, because eligibility is specifically related to the elderly. Some key workers can be vaccinated, but exclusively those working with the elderly, so I considered this not enough to code it as 2 groups (elderly + key workers).

C (elderly + staff of elderly homes + people living with elderly)     http://web.archive.org/web/20210115155202/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/vaccination-mot-covid-19/rekommendationer-for-vaccination-mot-covid-19/    Vaccine used: Pfizer/BioNTech    http://web.archive.org/web/20210115155721/https://www.regeringen.se/artiklar/2020/12/vaccinering-mot-covid-19-inleds-den-27-december/    The Public Health Agency's latest statistics show that Sweden has now vaccinated about 80,000 people.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210115155402/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/vaccination-mot-covid-19/statistik-over-vaccinerade-mot-covid-19/

Posters in Tajikistan developed by UNICEF and the Ministry of Education and Science (MoES) containing public health advice, including information on social distancing and handwashing. These materials were distributed to a total of 662 kindergartens, 1,771 ECD centres, and 3,884 schools covering all 68 districts and population centres around the country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112084049/https://www.unicef.org/eca/stories/children-tajikistan-return-safer-schools-amid-covid-19

"Additionally, while there is no official ban on public gatherings, authorities in Ashgabat have deactivated ATMs in shopping centers and semi-enclosed market areas, including the Terkinsky bazaar, to prevent crowds from congregating. "Is public transportation operating? Yes  Masks are required in most public places, including public transit."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104063536/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Rail services are suspended.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104064017/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

"Security forces have erected checkpoints on roads entering Ashgabat. Checkpoints have also been reported on highways in Balkan, Mary, Lebap, and Dashoguz provinces, where health screenings have been carried out. Special permits are required for travel within or between provinces."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104064217/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/423761/turkmenistan-authorities-extend-covid-19-related-international-and-domestic-travel-restrictions-until-at-least-jan-31-update-8

"All international scheduled commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan have been suspended.    At present, entry to Turkmenistan is prohibited except for Turkmen nationals and accredited diplomats, permanently registered foreigners and some employees of international companies and organisations"    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104064916/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/entry-requirements    "As part of ongoing efforts to limit the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19), authorities in Turkmenistan have extended their suspensions of international flights until at least Jan. 31. Domestic rail and bus services also remain suspended until at least Jan. 31. All land borders with Afghanistan, Iran, Kazakhstan, and Uzbekistan remain closed until further notice. Only Turkmen nationals, permanent residents, diplomats, and workers in critical industries and key infrastructure are permitted to enter the country. All arrivals must undergo a 14-day quarantine in a state-run facility. While freight traffic is generally allowed to transit the border, Turkmen authorities have previously restricted cross-border freight traffic without warning or explanation. All persons departing the country must be in possession of a negative COVID-19 test certificate, signed within the previous 24 hours."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210104064217/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/423761/turkmenistan-authorities-extend-covid-19-related-international-and-domestic-travel-restrictions-until-at-least-jan-31-update-8
"It is compulsory to wear a facemask when in public."  http://web.archive.org/web/20210104064017/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

Starting with 30th of December, all travelers who arrive in Turkey through air, land or sea will be asked to present a negative PCR test result document issued 72 ours prior to arrival. Those who fail to do so at the border gate or seaport will be quarantined in the address to where they are going. Travelers who arrived in Turkey from United Kingdom, Denmark or South Africa in the past 10 days will be asked to present a negative test result done within the past 72 hours, and also will be required to quarantine in the address to where they are going.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/symcM

From 19 December 2020, new restrictions will apply throughout Ukraine.   Acc. to these new restrictions it is forbidden:  - Carrying out mass events (performances, holiday concerts) in educational institutions with the participation of children from more than one group/class and in the presence of visitors.  - Carrying out festive events, banquets, master classes, public events in public catering establishments and entertainment facilities.  - Reception of visitors in museums, exhibitions, galleries if there are more than 1 visitor per 10m2.  - Operation of public catering establishments from 22:00 to 7:00 (except for delivery of takeaway orders). Payment transactions are prohibited after 22:00. During the night of December 31– January 1 the work of restaurants and cafes will be allowed until 01:00.  - Conducting religious events indoors upon condition that there will be present more than 1 person per 5 square meters; religious events open-air not keeping the requirement of maintaining physical distance 1.5 meters between those present.    Restrictions that continue to be in force (what is still forbidden):  • Staying in transport and public places without a mask, being outside without documents. • Unauthorized leave of the observation place. • Carrying out of mass cultural, sports, social, advertising and other actions in which more than 20 persons take part and not preserving physical distance 1.5 meters between participants (with some exceptions). • Operation of cinemas and cultural facilities with more than 50% occupancy per hall. • Carriage of more passengers in passenger transport than the number of seats (except metro). • Work of discos, night clubs and operation of public catering establishments with the organization of leisure. • Not abiding the demand to preserve a physical distance of 2 meters between the tables and to place a maximum number of 4 people at one table. • The work of business entities in which employees are not provided with masks, no markings are applied to the distance of 1.5 meters between customers, and visitors not properly wearing personal protective equipment. • Crossing the border for foreigners without an existing insurance policy (with some exceptions). • Activities of accommodation facilities (except hotels). • Visiting by a group of more than 20 persons of educational institutions, except for preschool, general secondary, out-of-school and specialized education institutions. • Visiting preschool, general secondary, out-of-school, sports and art education institutions when more than 50% of students and staff of the educational institution stay in self-isolation. • Carrying out planned hospitalization (with exceptions). • Operation of gyms, fitness centers and museums, if they allow more than 1 person per 20 m2. • Visiting places of temporary detention of persons, places of temporary stay of foreigners and stateless persons, accommodation places for refugees. • Crossing the checkpoints with the temporarily occupied territories of separate areas of Donetsk and Luhansk regions (ORDLO) and Crimea by foreigners without an existing insurance policy (with some exceptions). • Visits to social protection institutions with the stay of persons of certain categories (persons of senior age, war veterans, people with disabilities, mental disorders, etc.).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201220102241/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/uryadom-zaprovadzheno-perelik-karantinnih-obmezhen-yaki-diyatimut-z-19-grudnya-2020-roku-na-vsij-teritoriyi-ukrayini

No change to policies regarding school closures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210110172936/https://moz.gov.ua/article/reform-plan/maksim-stepanov-moz-napoljagae-na-vvedenni-zaplanovanogo-posilenogo-karantinu-z-8-do-24-sichnja

Ukraine government implements extended quarantine measures as announced on 9th December 2020. The enhanced measures will be in place from 00:00 on the 8th January 2021 until 00:00 on the 25th January 2021. These measures refer to the closing of all schools across Ukraine, the closing of most workplaces, and banning all public events.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210110165940/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/operativna-informacija-pro-poshirennja-koronavirusnoi-infekcii-2019-cov19    https://web.archive.org/web/20210110170949/https://moz.gov.ua/article/reform-plan/maksim-stepanov-vidsogodni-v-ukraini-vstupili-v-diju-posileni-karantinni-obmezhennja

"When in public buildings, and while travelling on public transport and in taxis, you must wear a protective mask covering your nose and mouth." Diagnostics will be carried out only in cases that correspond to the epidemiological and clinical definition of the disease specified in the WHO recommendations.
